title: Implement an extensible palette
body:
The default Graphiti palette is not ideal for Ptolemy/Triq editors for following reasons :

```
•  accordeon menu doesn't fit well for cases with many entries in many groups
•  how to represent sub-groups?
•  rather static way of defining the contents, based on predefined "create features". How to provide for dynamic customizations/extensions, provided by extra actor bundles etc?
```

A tree-based palette seems better suited for our needs, possible combined with a "favorites" container and a search field. (cfr passerelle).

So we need the following :

```
•  disable std Graphiti/GEF palette
•  maybe use that screen space to show a favorites panel
•  implement a tree-based palette view
•  use an extensions-based approach to define the palette contents. It can be based on a combination of concepts from eclipse menu extensions and the implementation in passerelle.
```

In a second phase we could allow the user to reconfigure the palette contents in a preferences page and/or using a context menu in the palette.

title: Add support for plain composite actors as "sub models"
body:
Ptolemy allows to use CompositeActors in a model in two ways :

```
•  "plain" composites whose contents are persisted in the same (moml) file as the parent model
•  "actor-oriented classes" that are defined in separate moml files, referenced from the parent model
```

In a first phase we will add support for plain composites as a way to represent hierarchical models.

title: NA
body:
Current implementation should be sufficient for a 0.1.0 release.
More work needed afterwards, which will be described in new issues.

title: Support code for workflow definition and execution unit tests
body: Passerelle has unit test support APIs, actor implementations etc that can be migrated to Triquetrum.

title: NA
body:
Some of this test support is already migrated in PtII and in Triquetrum.

But we need some improvements in integrating both feature-sets. 

PtII ModelExecutionAssertion is not applicable now on a model being executed by Triquetrum's WorkflowExecutionService. This is because a model enriched to collect execution statistics and then passed to Triquetrum's service, is internally cloned first. The cloning loses some of the statistics collection stuff (_actorFiringListeners in particular).

To resolve this without breaking Triquetrum service APIs, we could manage the setup of execution statistics inside the execution service, e.g. always when running in DEBUG mode.

The invoking code (e.g. unit tests) can then apply assertions on the model as can be found in the ProcessHandle. E.g. similar to:

    ProcessHandle procHandle = processingService.start(StartMode.DEBUG, model, null, null, null);
    processingService.waitUntilFinished(procHandle, 10, TimeUnit.MINUTES);
    
    new ModelExecutionAssertion()
    .expectActorIterationCount(..., 1L)
    .expectMsgReceiptCount(..., 1L)
    .expectMsgSentCount(..., 1L)
    .assertModel(procHandle.getModel());

title: Provide a simple console view to show workflow execution logs etc
body:
Currently, the Triq editor logs most of its info to system.out via a log4j console appender.
When launching the Triq editor from inside an eclipse workspace, this shows the logs in the run console of the "parent eclipse" instance, from where you launched Triq.

In a standalone Triq editor RCP, such logs are currently not yet visible.

So we need to provide a "local" console view, integrated in the workflow editor RCP application.

title: NA
body:
The implementation of the console initialisation is in TriqEditorPlugin, and it is invoked from the moment a model is executed, i.e. in RunFeature.

A plain Log4J ConsoleAppender will then see its output redirected to this Triq Console.

title: Integrate Ptolemy II's Display actor in an RCP workbench
body:
Provide an implemention of Ptolemy II's ptolemy.actor.lib.gui.DisplayInterface and ptolemy.actor.injection.PortableContainer on SWT views & windows.

Then we can already run simple models that show some data in a UI, using the Display actor.

We must also provide a default implementation and accompanying example use cases.

title: Add pom.xml file so that we can build from the command line.
body:
To add this project to Eclipse's Continuous Integration (CI) system, we need to be able to build it from the command line.

To do this, I need to build from the command line using Tycho, which uses Maven.

(Historical note: long ago, the Ptolemy Project had a Tcl/Tk based IDE called Tycho)

To create a Maven pom.xml file, the Eclipse Tycho Tutorial at http://www.vogella.com/tutorials/EclipseTycho/article.html#maventycho_generatepom1 suggests that we do: 

> mvn org.eclipse.tycho:tycho-pomgenerator-plugin:generate-poms -DgroupId=triquetrum

I checked out a clean Triquetrum tree, ran the above command and the pom.xml was created:

> bash-3.2$ git clone https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/
> Cloning into 'triquetrum'...
> remote: Counting objects: 897, done.  
> remote: Total 897 (delta 0), reused 0 (delta 0), pack-reused 896  
> Receiving objects: 100% (897/897), 7.63 MiB | 877.00 KiB/s, done.
> Resolving deltas: 100% (294/294), done.
> Checking connectivity... done.
> bash-3.2$ cd triquetrum/
> bash-3.2$ mvn org.eclipse.tycho:tycho-pomgenerator-plugin:generate-poms -DgroupId=triquetrum
> [INFO] Scanning for projects...
> [INFO]
> [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
> [INFO] Building Maven Stub Project (No POM) 1
> [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
> [INFO]
> [INFO] --- tycho-pomgenerator-plugin:0.24.0:generate-poms (default-cli) @ standalone-pom ---
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/branches basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/hooks basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/info basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/logs basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/logs/refs basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/logs/refs/heads basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/logs/refs/remotes basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/logs/refs/remotes/origin basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/objects basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/objects/info basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/objects/pack basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/refs basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/refs/heads basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/refs/remotes basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/refs/remotes/origin basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/.git/refs/tags basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform/target basedir
> [INFO] Scanning /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform/target/plugins basedir
> [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
> [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
> [INFO] BUILD SUCCESS
> [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
> [INFO] Total time: 0.666 s
> [INFO] Finished at: 2016-01-18T11:01:02-08:00
> [INFO] Final Memory: 12M/309M
> [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------

To avoid creating pom.xml files in each directory, https://wiki.eclipse.org/Tycho/Release_Notes/0.24#POM-less_Tycho_builds suggests creating a .mvn/extensions.xml file, which I did:

> bash-3.2$ mkdir .mvn
> bash-3.2$ cp ../../triquetrum/.mvn/extensions.xml .mvn

Ok, so the next step is to run Maven.

The Eclipse Tycho Tutorial states:

> "Tip: It is not recommended to use the mvn clean install command, instead you should use mvn clean verify. If you would use the install option, the build result would be installed in your local Maven repository and this can lead to build problems."

The tutorial also states:

> "Warning If you try to execute this POM file, the build fail because you have not yet configured your dependencies." 

Indeed, just running "mvn clean" fails because "package ptolemy.data 10.1.0" is not found:

> bash-3.2$ mvn clean
> [INFO] Scanning for projects...
> [WARNING] No explicit target runtime environment configuration. Build is platform dependent.
> [WARNING] No explicit target runtime environment configuration. Build is platform dependent.
> [WARNING] No explicit target runtime environment configuration. Build is platform dependent.
> [WARNING] No explicit target runtime environment configuration. Build is platform dependent.
> [WARNING] No explicit target runtime environment configuration. Build is platform dependent.
> [WARNING] No explicit target runtime environment configuration. Build is platform dependent.
> [WARNING] No explicit target runtime environment configuration. Build is platform dependent.
> [WARNING] No explicit target runtime environment configuration. Build is platform dependent.
> [WARNING] No explicit target runtime environment configuration. Build is platform dependent.
> [WARNING] No explicit target runtime environment configuration. Build is platform dependent.
> [WARNING] No explicit target runtime environment configuration. Build is platform dependent.
> [WARNING] No explicit target runtime environment configuration. Build is platform dependent.
> (BTW - I looked at the ICE pom.xml to attempt to set the target for Triquetrum, but had no success.)
> [INFO] Computing target platform for MavenProject: triquetrum:org.eclipse.triquetrum.common:1.0.0-SNAPSHOT @ /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/org.eclipse.triquetrum.common/pom.xml
> [INFO] Resolving dependencies of MavenProject: triquetrum:org.eclipse.triquetrum.common:1.0.0-SNAPSHOT @ /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/org.eclipse.triquetrum.common/pom.xml
> [INFO] {osgi.os=macosx, osgi.ws=cocoa, org.eclipse.update.install.features=true, osgi.arch=x86_64}
> [ERROR] Cannot resolve project dependencies:
> [ERROR]   Software being installed: org.eclipse.triquetrum.common 1.0.0.qualifier
> [ERROR]   Missing requirement: org.eclipse.triquetrum.common 1.0.0.qualifier requires 'package ptolemy.data 10.1.0' but it could not be found
> [ERROR]
> [ERROR] See http://wiki.eclipse.org/Tycho/Dependency_Resolution_Troubleshooting for help.
> [ERROR] Cannot resolve dependencies of MavenProject: triquetrum:org.eclipse.triquetrum.common:1.0.0-SNAPSHOT @ /Users/cxh/src/triquetrum/tmp/triquetrum/org.eclipse.triquetrum.common/pom.xml: See log for details -> [Help 1]
> [ERROR]
> [ERROR] To see the full stack trace of the errors, re-run Maven with the -e switch.
> [ERROR] Re-run Maven using the -X switch to enable full debug logging.
> [ERROR]
> [ERROR] For more information about the errors and possible solutions, please read the following articles:
> [ERROR] [Help 1] http://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/MavenExecutionException
> bash-3.2$
> Ok, not surprising, triquetrum/org.eclipse.triquetrum.common/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF contains:
> 
> Import-Package: ptolemy.data;version="10.1.0",
>  ptolemy.kernel.util

triquetrum/./org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform/target/plugins/ptolemy.core_11.0.0.201511291558.jar is the jar file that contains ptolemy.data.   That jar files MANIFEST.MF includes:

> Export-Package: org.ptolemy.osgi;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.actor;versio
>  n="11.0.0",ptolemy.actor.parameters;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.actor.sc
>  hed;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.actor.util;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.data
>  ;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.data.expr;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.data.typ
>  e;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.data.unit;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.graph;v
>  ersion="11.0.0",ptolemy.graph.analysis;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.graph
>  .analysis.analyzer;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.graph.analysis.strategy;v
>  ersion="11.0.0",ptolemy.graph.mapping;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.kernel
>  ;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.kernel.attributes;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.
>  kernel.undo;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.kernel.util;version="11.0.0",pto
>  lemy.math;version="11.0.0",ptolemy.util;version="11.0.0"
> Note that the MANIFEST.MF above has "ptolemy.data.expr;version="11.0.0" and we are looking for the 10.1.0 version, but this should work (right?)

So, now the question is: how to get Tycho to know where these dependencies are.

In a perfect world, we could use the Maven dependency facility in the pom.xml file, but this is not how Eclipse and Tycho work for various good reasons.

It looks to me like I would need to put these up on an Eclipse p2 server.  I'm assuming that I could host one of these?  Is this correct?  There was also some ideas of using jetty to bring up a local p2 server for our jar files.

The p2-maven-plugin at http://projects.reficio.org/p2-maven-plugin/1.1.0/manual.html looks useful.

This stackoverflow post looks helpful: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13268213/how-to-use-directory-containing-third-party-bundles-in-a-tycho-build

As does this, but it is not a perfect fit: https://wiki.eclipse.org/Tycho/Dependency_Resolution_Troubleshooting

Jay suggested:

> I think you are on the right track. What I did in ICE to handle third party dependencies that weren't available at a p2 site was to create an org.eclipse.ice.dependencies bundle
> 
> https://github.com/jayjaybillings/ICEDeps/tree/master/org.eclipse.ice.dependencies
> 
> This bundle includes the dependencies on its classpath and exports them. Then, any other bundle that uses them just does an Import-Package call in their manifest and is good to go.

Erwin wrote:

> Great that you're taking up this task. I think that to get things working quickly, Jay's approach is the easiest for now, i.e. we put all dependencies as jars inside a wrapper bundle that then exports all Java packages from there. It would be a straightforward redefinition of what is now org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform.
> 
> A very promising tool to get a flexible build repository is Package Drone, presented at eclipse con last year.
> It offers a multi-"protocol" repository including p2, std maven etc.
> But I guess that would take some experimenting first to get it working.

I'll create a branch with my pom.xml and .mvn/extension.xml file.

title: CreateFeatures do not yet create unique names for model elements
body:
ConnectionCreateFeature still uses a fixed name, while ModelElementCreateFeature uses the name defined in the palette.

The user can still adapt an actor name manually, but the editor does not yet help out by proposing a unique name form the start.
For connections there's even no way currently to change the name.

This naturally leads to errors in ptolemy's model layer once you go beyond a trivial hello world model.

title: NA
body: We can integrate ptolemy.kernel.CompositeEntity.uniqueName(String) into the logic of the create features.

title: Create a CapeCode Triquetrum product
body:
The Ptolemy group at Berkeley are developing [Cape Code](http://capecode.org), which uses [Accessors](http://accessors.org) as proxies to interact with the IoT.

CapeCode uses Ptolemy II, which has the notion of configurations that presents to the user different sets of actors and other features.

It would be helpful if we could have a CapeCode configuration in Triquetrum.  This would probably be a separate product that included a separate palette.

In Ptolemy II, the CapeCode configuration may be found in `ptII/ptolemy/configs/capecode/`.

CapeCode uses Nashorn, so Java 1.8 would be required. 

Currently, to make this work, we would need to create a set of jar files that contain the Ptolemy classes.

The UI would need to be extended so that we have things like:
- Hierarchical models
- Hierarchical actor palettes
- Support for dragging in attributes
  - Textual Annotations in the model

title: NA
body:
This is on hold because we need to use OSGi bundles for the PtII code because we are depending on bundle activation.  The Tycho build uses a non-OSGi bundles for the PtII code because Tycho can only access bundles in Software Sites.

http://www.vogella.com/tutorials/EclipseTycho/article.html#tychotargetplatform says:

> Tycho only supports Software Sites as locations. Directory, Installation and Feature are not supported and are ignored by the build process.

title: NA
body:
Now that Erwin has fixed up the Triqiuetrum build using Tycho, we can build RCP images, so supporting CapeCode can proceed.

To get a list of which jar files are used by CapeCode

```
cd $PTII
make echo_jars JARS=CAPECODE_JNLP_JARS | grep .jar | awk -F \" '{print $2}' | sort | uniq | sed 's@../dists/ptII11.0.devel/jar_dist/@@'
```

See [capecodeJars.txt](https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/files/133120/capecodeJars.txt)

The list of packages that are used by the StockTick demo can be found by doing:

```
export JAVAFLAGS=-verbose
$PTII/bin/vergil $PTII/org/terraswarm/accessor/demo/StockTick/StockTick.xml >& /tmp/classes.txt
grep 'Loaded ' /tmp/classes.txt | awk '{print $2}' | sort | uniq | awk -F . '{ for(i=1;i<NF;i++) printf("%s.", $i); printf("\n")}' | sort | uniq > ~/tmp/packages.txt
```

See [capecodePackages.txt](https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/files/133121/capecodePackages.txt)

title: NA
body:
Note that Cape Code is not a blocker for the Triquetrum First Release: 21st October 2016 #71 

At first, because it would take awhile to get the CQs done, the Cape Code sources will not be checked in to the Eclipse Repo.

title: NA
body:
One issue here is that the Cape Code configuration consists of a multiple Accessors, where each Accessor is an instance of org.terraswarm.accessor.jjs.JSAccessor, but has different values for the script parameter.  It is not clear to me how we would create an Actor bundle that will support this.

http://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Extending_Triquetrum#Creating_an_actor_bundle describes how to create an actor bundle where each actor is implemented by a Java class.

However, in Cape Code, we have multiple actors that each implement org.terraswarm.accessor.jjs.JSAccessor.

BTW - When `$PTII/bin/vergil -capecode` is run, there is an Accessors node in the actor tree view.  When that node is opened, org/terraswarm/accessor/AccessorLibrary.java gets https://www.terraswarm.org/accessors/index.json which contains:

```
[
    "audio",
    "cameras",
    "devices",
    "gdp",
    "image",
    "net",
    "robotics",
    "geodesy",
    "services",
    "signals",
    "test",
    "utilities"
]
```

Each of the elements represents a directory, so https://www.terraswarm.org/accessors/audio/index.json is opened, which contains:

```

[
    "AudioCapture.js",
    "AudioPlayer.js",
    "ClipPlayer.js"
]
```

https://www.terraswarm.org/accessors/audio/AudioCapture.js is opened and passed to the accessorToMoML() method in org/terraswarm/accessor/JSAccessor.java, which returns MoML that looks like

```
<entity name="AudioCapture" class="org.terraswarm.accessor.jjs.JSAccessor">
  <property name="accessorSource" value="https://www.terraswarm.org/accessors/audio/AudioCapture.js"/>
  <input source="file:/Users/cxh/ptII/org/terraswarm/accessor/accessors/web/audio/AudioCapturePtDoc.xml"/>
  <property name="script" value="..."
  <property name="_tableauFactory" class="ptolemy.vergil.toolbox.TextEditorTableauFactory">
    <property name="attributeName" value="script"/>
    <property name="syntaxStyle" value="text/javascript"/>
  </property>
  <property name="script">
    <property name="style" class="ptolemy.actor.gui.style.NoteStyle">
      <property name="note" value="NOTE: To see the script, invoke Open Actor"/>
    </property>
  </property>
</entity>
```

So, what we need to do is modify the bundle activator to do the above access of the index.json files and instantiation.

title: NA
body:
Christopher, could you send me a concrete example of the capecode configuration of some accessors?

I think what you need is to be able to add multiple entries in the palette definition, based on a same underlying actor Java class, each with some different parameters/properties. And this is already possible in theory in Triquetrum. I.e. we can set properties on actors in the palette. But this has not yet been used/proven and may not be sufficient. 

I looked around in ptII/ptolemy/configs/capecode/ but it seems the real accessor configuration info should come from : 

```
<!-- Standard TerraSwarm accessors. -->
<entity name="Accessors" class="org.terraswarm.accessor.AccessorLibrary">
  <configure source="https://www.terraswarm.org/accessors"/>
</entity>
```

and I could not see the XML there that could show how an accessor actor is defined in a capecode configuration. 

Or is this done based on what you describe above, i.e. there's some js/json files that get transformed by the JSAccessor actor code itself?

If the last part of your comment means that the palette is not known/defined upfront in a Vergil configuration, but is generated on the fly each time, reading the json/js file on the terraswarm URL, I can see several issues : 
- What happens when you're working off-line? Can you only design capecode models when being on-line?
- Triquetrum does not support dynamically changing palettes yet. This should be technically feasible, but won't be available before Tuesday, the deadline for the newsletter...
- What is the "input" element for in the MOML fragment above? Is that only needed to include a help document for the actor? (which we don't support yet anyway in Triquetrum)

title: NA
body:
Here's a zip file of the configuration.  I created it by editing ptolemy/configs/test/configTest.tcl:

```
bash-3.2$ svn diff ptolemy/configs/test/configTest.tcl
Index: ptolemy/configs/test/configTest.tcl
===================================================================
--- ptolemy/configs/test/configTest.tcl (revision 75383)
+++ ptolemy/configs/test/configTest.tcl (working copy)
@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@

     set loader [[$parser getClass] getClassLoader]

-set URL [$loader getResource ptolemy/configs/ptiny/configuration.xml]
+set URL [$loader getResource ptolemy/configs/capecode/configuration.xml]
 puts "Checking [$URL toString]"
 set object [$parser {parse java.net.URL java.net.URL} $URL $URL]
 set configuration [java::cast ptolemy.kernel.CompositeEntity $object]
@@ -57,5 +57,7 @@
 set results [[java::cast ptolemy.actor.gui.Configuration $configuration] check]
 puts $results

+puts [$configuration exportMoML]
+
 # The list of filters is static, so we reset it
 java::call ptolemy.moml.MoMLParser setMoMLFilters [java::null]
bash-3.2$ 
```

and then running

$PTII/bin/ptjacl configTest.tcl >& ~/tmp/capeCodeConfiguration.xml

and then editing that file and removing some text from the beginning.

Here's the file:

[capeCodeConfiguration.xml.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/files/586137/capeCodeConfiguration.xml.zip)

Below are some answers to your questions:

In Vergil, the palette is created when the Accessors tab in the actor palette is opened.  Vergil has lazy evaluation of the elements in the actor palette.  This means that startup is fast and if there are problems with a set of actors, they don't cause problems until you try to use them.  If you search the actors for an actor by name, then each set of actors is opened as the search proceeds.

If you are working offline, then Cape Code looks in $PTII/org/terraswarm/accessor/accessors/web for the accessors.  In fact, it looks there first and then looks at the website.

How the AccessorLibrary class works is that it looks for a index.json file that names directories that contain index.json files.  These second-level index.json files name .js files that define the accessors.  The accessor .js files are read in and then converted to MoML, which is then parsed and added to the configuration.  I think we will want the bundle activator to do this parsing for us.

The input element causes the MoMLParser to read input from a file as if the contents of that file were present in the MoML.

Not getting this done by Tuesday is not a problem.  I'm on holiday today.

In other news, I added org.terraswarm.accessor to osgi-2-0/.  When I run `mvn clean verify`, the build fails for the following reasons.
1. The version of ptolemy.data.expr.Constants in osgi-2-0 is missing the nameToType(type) method.  We need to figure out a policy about how to update existing files in the Ptolemy II bundles that have passed IP CQ.  I propose that we bump the version numbers,make changes and then submit the changes to IPCQ.   We need to refine and document how this is done.
2. io.vertx.core.AbstractVerticle is not found.  This code uses Vert.x, I need to figure out how to require it in pom.xml
3. ptolemy.data.ImageToken and ptolemy.util.StringBufferExec are not present.  We should consider adding these files to the bundles.

My idea is to get the above to compile and then work on the activator.  I'm not going to get much done today.

body:
I have a first hacked-together result, combining the triquetrum branch #189 with a capecode palette provider in https://github.com/erwindl0/triquetrum-capecode, a set of 3rdparty deps like jackson and netty and local hacks in ptII code...

The palette provider adds the BaseA.js test accessor to the Triquetrum palette.

![capecodetriquetrum](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461921/20832842/cd981e08-b88c-11e6-9205-3f92ca3f0116.JPG)

Main purpose is to try to understand what it takes, the code or workspace setup is not OK at all for real usage.

Besides updating some ptII classes (as mentioned previously by Christopher as well), I see following issues that must be addressed, both in ptII Java code and in JavaScript files (at least these are things I am aware of at this moment, we may discover more...) :

Things that are not compatible with OSGi-based modularity : 
- usage of $CLASSPATH in file/resource/module lookup code
- loading JavaScript and JSON files with locations relative to specific Java classes in the ptII package
- maintaining accessor/node modules in a single aggregated tree

I copied the files on some fixed local paths and changed the lookup code in some places to point there i.o. using $CLASSPATH-relative paths etc.

Triquetrum-specific issues for CapeCode : 
- I have the impression that the BaseA accessor does not automatically get its extra inputs from the JavaScript :
`
exports.setup = function () {
    this.input('in1');
    console.log('base set up');
}
`
Should the BaseA accessor get an 'in1' input port? For the moment it only has a 'script' input port and an 'error' output port. Is there some actor lifecycle method to invoke before rendering it in the editor?

title: NA
body:
Cool, thanks for taking a look!  This looks promising.

About $CLASSPATH, I spent some time last week getting Cape Code to work when run from just jar files (I think).  The code unjars files and directories to a temporary location and then reads files from that location.  The temporary files are deleted upon exit.  This is a half step, a better solution would be to read the jar files and provide the content of the files without creating a temporary file.  We do this for the Duktape-based accessor hosts.  (Duktape is a JavaScript interpreter written in C.  org/terraswarm/accessor/accessors/adm/hosts/duktape/eduk is a Duktape host that is meant for an embedded platform that has no file system, instead the contents of the .js files are encoded in arrays.)

I can see why $CLASSPATH would be a problem with OSGi.  It would be really helpful to be able to support $CLASSPATH.  If we can't support it, we need something similar.  As a workaround, for CapeCode we could just provide either a directory tree that has .js files or a jar file that has the .js files that gets unjared. 

About your BaseA accessor, the input port "in1" should be created.

The way this works is that  ptolemy/actor/lib/jjs/JavaScript.java has _createEngineAndEvaluateSetup(), which contains:

```
        // Create proxies for the port.   
        // Note that additional proxies may need to be created in initialize(),      
	// if they are created by a setup() function call.   
        _proxies = new HashMap<NamedObj, PortOrParameterProxy>();
        _proxiesByName = new HashMap<String, PortOrParameterProxy>();
        for (TypedIOPort port : portList()) {
            // Do not convert the script or error ports to a JavaScript variable.  
            if (port == script.getPort() || port == error) {
                continue;
            }
            PortOrParameterProxy proxy = new PortOrParameterProxy(port);
            _proxies.put(port, proxy);
            _proxiesByName.put(port.getName(), proxy);
        }
```
I think the comment about initialize might not be accurate.

I created a model with a BaseA JavaScript actor that has your JavaScript code in it.  The model is here:

[BaseA.xml.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/files/627565/BaseA.xml.zip)

Looking at the xml, the port is present:

```
    <entity name="JavaScript" class="ptolemy.actor.lib.jjs.JavaScript">
        <property name="script" class="ptolemy.actor.parameters.PortParameter" value="exports.setup = function () { this.input('in1'); console.log('base se\
t up'); }">
            <property name="style" class="ptolemy.actor.gui.style.NoteStyle">
                <property name="note" class="ptolemy.kernel.util.StringAttribute" value="NOTE: To see the script, invoke Open Actor">
                </property>
            </property>
        </property>
        <property name="_tableauFactory" class="ptolemy.vergil.toolbox.TextEditorTableauFactory">
            <property name="attributeName" class="ptolemy.kernel.util.StringAttribute" value="script">
            </property>
            <property name="syntaxStyle" class="ptolemy.kernel.util.StringAttribute" value="text/javascript">
            </property>
        </property>
        <property name="_location" class="ptolemy.kernel.util.Location" value="{295, 165}">
        </property>
        <port name="in1" class="ptolemy.actor.TypedIOPort">
            <property name="input"/>
            <property name="defaultValue" class="ptolemy.data.expr.Parameter">
            </property>
        </port>
    </entity>
```

When I open the model, stdout shows that setup() is invoked:

```
bash-3.2$ $PTII/bin/vergil -capecode ~/tmp/BaseA.xml   
JavaScript: base set up (Thread[AWT-EventQueue-0,6,main])     
JavaScript: base set up (Thread[AWT-EventQueue-0,6,main]) 
```

I'm not sure why it is invoked twice, that seems buggy.

I'll take a look at your code and see what changes you had to make.  I'm working a short day today and not working much over the weekend, so it might be Monday before I get to this.

Something I had forgotten to mention before : I also had to remove the 
moml parts about NoteStyle and TextEditorTableauFactory, as they're 
linked to Vergil-specific classes that are not in the Ptolemy II OSGi 
bundles. A more ambitious approach would be to try to implement these 
concepts on Eclipse RCP technology, but that's too complex for me...

body:
Removing NoteStyle and TextEditorTableauFactory seems reasonable to me.  In Vergil, NoteStyle just modifies the parameter configuration window with a note that says "To see the script, invoke Open Actor".  In Vergil, TextEditorTableauFactory brings up an editor for the .js.

I took a look at your code and it looks like you are loading in capeCodeHost.xml and localFunctions.xml with an absolute path that is Windows-dependent which is fine in the near term.

One possible change that is missing is that ./ptolemy.gui/original-src/ptolemy/actor/gui/JNLPUtilities.java should probably be updated to get my change that will copy a directory from a jar file to a temporary location.  I'm not sure if this will change things, but it might.

BTW - I'm still working on actor/lib/jjs/NashornAccessoHostApplication.java

That file loads a composite accessor and, if it worked, might be a good quick test.  

However, it is non-deterministic, so I suggest avoiding it.
                                                                                                                                         
```
bash-3.2$ (cd $PTII/org/terraswarm/accessor/accessors/web/hosts; java -classpath $PTII ptolemy.actor.lib.jjs.NashornAccessorHostApplication -accessor -timeout 10000 hosts/nashorn/test/testNashornHost.js)                                                                                                            
TestAdder: inputLeft: 10 inputRight: 0   
TestGain: input 10 gain: 4      
TestAdder: inputLeft: 10 inputRight: 40     
TestAdder: inputLeft: 10 inputRight: 40     
50                                                                                                                                                          
bash-3.2$ (cd $PTII/org/terraswarm/accessor/accessors/web/hosts; java -classpath $PTII ptolemy.actor.lib.jjs.NashornAccessorHostApplication -accessor -timeout 10000 hosts/nashorn/test/testNashornHost.js)                                                                                                            
TestGain: input 10 gain: 4      
TestGain: input 10 gain: 4   
TestAdder: inputLeft: 10 inputRight: 40     
undefined                                                                                                                                                   
bash-3.2$ 
```

body:
I'm somewhat stuck here and could use some help

Triquetrum uses Vert.x, so I would like osgi-2.0/org.terraswarm.accessor to some how require vert.x

I was thinking that osgi-2-0/pom.xml would contain:

```
    <module>org.terraswarm.accessor</module> 
```

and osgi-2-0/org.terraswarm.accessor/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF would contain:

```
Require-Bundle: ptolemy.moml;bundle-version="11.0.0",
 vertx-core;bundle-version="3.3.3"
```
because https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/io.vertx/vertx-core/3.3.3 includes the following code for maven:

```
<!-- https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/io.vertx/vertx-core -->
<dependency>
    <groupId>io.vertx</groupId>
    <artifactId>vertx-core</artifactId>
    <version>3.3.3</version>
</dependency>
```

However, that does not work, probably because Tycho is not looking for the Maven repository or because the Maven file is not correct.

I do have  ~/.m2/repository/io/vertx/vertx-core/3.3.3/vertx-core-3.3.3.jar

and the META-INF/MANIFEST.MF of vertx-core-3.3.3.jar contains:

```
Bundle-SymbolicName: io.vertx.core
...
Bundle-Name: Vert.x Core
Bundle-Version: 3.3.3
Maven-Version: 3.3.3
Created-By: Apache Maven Bundle Plugin
Build-Jdk: 1.8.0_92
Maven-Group-Id: io.vertx
```

I tried modifying osgi-2-0/org.terraswarm.accessor/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF to

```
Require-Bundle: ptolemy.moml;bundle-version="11.0.0",
 Vert.x Core;bundle-version="3.3.3"
```
and

```
Require-Bundle: ptolemy.moml;bundle-version="11.0.0",
 io.vertx.core;bundle-version="3.3.3"
```
but neither one worked, for the latter case, `mvn clean verify` resulted in:

```
[ERROR] Cannot resolve project dependencies:
[ERROR]   Software being installed: org.terraswarm.accessor 11.0.0.qualifier
[ERROR]   Missing requirement: org.terraswarm.accessor 11.0.0.qualifier requires 'bundle io.vertx.core 3.3.3' but it could not be found
[ERROR]
[ERROR] See http://wiki.eclipse.org/Tycho/Dependency_Resolution_Troubleshooting for help.
[ERROR] Cannot resolve dependencies of MavenProject: org.ptolemy.tycho:org.terraswarm.accessor:11.0.0-\
SNAPSHOT @ /Users/cxh/src/osgi-2-0/org.terraswarm.accessor/.polyglot.build.properties: See log for details -> [Help 1]
[ERROR]
[ERROR] To see the full stack trace of the errors, re-run Maven with the -e switch.
[ERROR] Re-run Maven using the -X switch to enable full debug logging.
[ERROR]
[ERROR] For more information about the errors and possible solutions, please read the following articles:
[ERROR] [Help 1] http://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/MavenExecutionException
```

Really what I need is a p2 repository that has the appropriate file.

https://github.com/glyn/vert.x.osgi has a bundling/ directory that will create vertx jar files that look OK to me.  

https://github.com/eclipse/vert.x/issues/708 is interesting.


There is https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/rt.vertx/releases/3.4.0

https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/vertx is of interest

https://www.eclipse.org/community/eclipse_newsletter/2016/october/article4.php uses maven, instead of an Eclipse p2 site.

However, shouldn't the Vert.x OSGi files be available somewhere in a p2 site?  Presumably they have passed CQ and there are signed jars somewhere?

If not, then I guess I need to add https://github.com/glyn/vert.x.osgi to the osgi-2-0 repo so that we can create the bundles, sign them and put them on the ptolemy p2 site.

title: NA
body:
Tycho by default only considers p2 sites, but you can set an extra flag "pomDependencies" to allow "standard" maven dependencies in addition to that, as follows : 

```
<plugin>
	<groupId>org.eclipse.tycho</groupId>
	<artifactId>target-platform-configuration</artifactId>
	<version>${tycho-version}</version>
	<configuration>
	  <pomDependencies>consider</pomDependencies>
	  <target>
...

```

Did you try that? Then I would expect that the vert.x core dependency (which is a valid bundle) is correctly found during the build.

But I never considered getting a build working ;-), just a trivial demo from my workspace...

title: NA
body: Thanks for the tip about pomDependencies. I used that to get `mvn verify` working. I also created two plugin projects by using File -> New -> Project -> Plug-in Development -> Plug-in from existing JAR archive. I created one for org.json, the other for io.vertx.core. One downside is that these two projects are missing something, so I can't yet deploy them on the osgi-2-0 p2 server. I was able to run a trivial example. A word of explanation is in order. The accessor system has what we call accessor hosts. Cape Code is an accessor host that allows combinations of Ptolemy actors and accessors. There is also a Nashorn host that is implemented in Java, but does not use Ptolemy actors, it only uses accessors. ptolemy/actor/lib/jjs/NashornAccessorHostApplication.java defines a main() method that invokes the Nashorn Accessor host. A simple test is: ``` bash-3.2$ (cd $PTII/org/terraswarm/accessor/accessors/web; $PTII/bin/ptinvoke ptolemy.actor.lib.jjs.Na\ shornAccessorHostApplication -timeout 10000 -js hosts/nashorn/test/testNashornHost.js) commonHost.js: processCommandLineArguments(): Setting timeout to stop after 10000 ms. Instantiated accessor TestComposite with class test/TestComposite TestAdder: fire(): inputLeft: 10 inputRight: 40 50 No standalone accessors were instantiated commonHost.js: processCommandLineArguments(): Maximum time reached. Calling stopAllAccessors(). ptolemy/actor/lib/jjs/modules/process/process.js: called exit() bash-3.2$ ``` To replicate this in a project that has the osgi-2-0 bundles: ``` svn co https://repo.eecs.berkeley.edu/svn/projects/eal/ptII/branches/osgi-2-0 ``` Then start up Eclipse, create a new empty workspace and import the projects from the directory created above. Create a Java Application: * Main tab: * Project: `org.terraswarm.accessor` * Main class: `ptolemy.actor.lib.jjs.NashornAccessorHostApplication` * Arguments tab: * Program Arguments: `-timeout 10000 nashorn/test/testNashornHost.js` * Working Directory: Use the location of the accessors repo in ptII. I used `/Users/cxh/ptII/org/terraswarm/accessor/accessors/web/hosts` * Classpath tab * Under User Entries, add the location of your PTII tree by clicking on "User Entries", then "Advanced", then "Add External Folder" and then enter the location of your PTII tree When the application is run, you should see something like: ``` Instantiated accessor TestComposite with class test/TestComposite java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException TestAdder: fire(): inputLeft: 10 inputRight: 40 50 ``` Clearly, we need to fix the ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. We also need to resolve things like how we find files and $CLASSPATH.

title: NA
body:
BTW - there was some interesting discussion about org.json at http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/incubation/msg00341.html

CapeCode uses org.json.  We have a copy of it in the ptII repo.  I wanted to provide org.json to Triquetrum, so I built an org.json bundle.

The incubation list at http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/incubation/msg00341.html has details about org.json.  Apparently there is a bundle in Orbit somewhere.  However, they have not been able to get the org.json author to agree to licensing terms on a more recent version.  There was a suggestion of using JSON-P.  

In the near term, we can do nothing. 

In the short term, we should see about using the org.json bundle in Orbit.

In the longer term, ptII should probably be migrated off of org.json.

title: Set up OSGi bundles for Ptolemy II source files
body:
Currently, we have a separate project for the Ptolemy II classes.

That project includes jar files created from the osgi-2-0 branch of the ptII repo.

See http://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/ptexternal for how to get access to the ptII repo.

It would be good to set up OSGi bundles for the Ptolemy II source files.

To do this would presumable require sign-off about the IP in those files.

Also, the package names would change, which would break compatibility.  FWIW- the MoMLParser includes a filter system (ptolemy.moml.filter) that might allow us to read old models and translate the class names.  This is a serious downside and basically a fork of the ptII tree.

Advantages include:
- We can start maintaining these files in CI
- Easier updates of the Triquetrum

title: NA
body:
We have OSGi files that bundle the Ptolemy II code.

The open issue now is: What do we need to do to check the source code for these bundles in to the Eclipse repo.

The first step is to get these bundles to pass the Eclipse IP process.  Ideally, this would be done in time for the October release.

To get these files checked in would require getting the authors to agree.  There are about 40,000 checkins, with about 100 authors.  About 30 of those authors are external, though most have made very few contributions.

The repository is created via a maven job run via Jenkins at http://terra.eecs.berkeley.edu:8080/job/ptIIosgi
My notes are at https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Ptolemy/osgi-2-0

The next steps would be to make it so that we can easily deploy OSGi bundles for random jar files.
http://www.vogella.com/tutorials/EclipseTycho/article.html#convertjars discusses how to do this.
Once we can convert jar files to bundles, then we could easily create the Cape Code jar files from within ptII, then generate the bundles.  This would give us a way to deploy Cape Code.

title: @see tags cause errors in Eclipse build
body:
In the triquetrum master branch, in triq.target, after I click on "Set As Target", I get three errors:

> Description    Resource    Path    Location    Type
> Access restriction: The type 'AbstractPlaceableJavaSE' is not API (restriction on required library '/Users/cxh/git/triquetrum/org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform/target/plugins/ptolemy.gui_11.0.0.201601200857.jar')    AbstractPlaceableSWT.java    /org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.ui/src/main/java/org/eclipse/triquetrum/workflow/ui    line 31    Java Problem
> Access restriction: The type 'SizeAttribute' is not API (restriction on required library '/Users/cxh/git/triquetrum/org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform/target/plugins/ptolemy.gui_11.0.0.201601200857.jar')    SizeAttribute.java    /org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.ui/src/main/java/org/eclipse/triquetrum/workflow/ui    line 40    Java Problem
> Access restriction: The type 'WindowPropertiesAttribute' is not API (restriction on required library '/Users/cxh/git/triquetrum/org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform/target/plugins/ptolemy.gui_11.0.0.201601200857.jar')    WindowPropertiesAttribute.java    /org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.ui/src/main/java/org/eclipse/triquetrum/workflow/ui    line 43    Java Problem

The first one is because org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.ui.AbstractPlaceableSWT has

>  @see ptolemy.actor.gui.AbstractPlaceableJavaSE

org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.ui.SizeAttribute has a similar issue with:

> - @see ptolemy.actor.gui.SizeAttribute

And org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.ui.WindowPropertiesAttribute has:

> - @see ptolemy.actor.gui.WindowPropertiesAttribute

Ideally users could create a workflow using the RCP editor for Triquetrum and then that workflow would show up in the list of Items that they can use in ICE. We could test this by creating a Triquetrum workflow that provides some sort of simple data analysis routine and hook that into ICE.

I'm working up some sketches now of the best way to hook this up to ICE. However, the short term hack is to obtain the ICE Core service from the OSGi and then when a new workflow is created for Triquetrum it can just be registered with the Core via an adapter ItemBuilder and Item.

http://terra.eecs.berkeley.edu:8080/job/triquetrum/warnings33

says we have 100 warnings, but that's probably because it stopped reporting after 100 warnings.

It would be good to address these because it promotes code reuse.  However, we could skip it for the Science2016Release if need be.

title: Implement "cancel" behaviour in actor configuration dialog
body:
The current integration of EMF forms in Triquetrum's NamedObjDialog to configure model elements (typically actors) does not yet provide for a correct "Cancel" button behaviour, that should be implemented somehow in our ActorConfigureFeature.

I.e. when a user makes some changes like renaming the actor and/or changing some parameter values, the changes are still applied after clicking on the Cancel button.

Graphiti's GFCommandStack runs the ActorConfigureFeature, and it seems there's no support to mark the EMF model changes/transaction for rollback when the user clicks the cancel button (or the dialog close x button). When throwing an exception (which was the only approach I found mentioned), e.g. an OperationCanceledException, model changes are indeed rolled back, but we get an ugly error stack trace in the logs each time.

I've asked for advice on https://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/1074195/

title: Add stop,pause,resume toolbar actions
body: We can already run workflows, but need to be able to stop them and to pause/resume them.

title: Integrate Ptolemy II's Plot actor in an RCP workbench
body:
The PtII plot abstraction APIs allow to plugin different UI component implementations (cfr #5 for a similar design for the Display actor) for graphical plots of datasets, time series etc.
The goal is to implement a version for SWT, using the Nebula XYGraph widget, able to show "native" PtII data tokens.

The first concrete use case is to support the PtII SequencePlotter actor.

Remark that the plot APIs are quite complex for a newbie like me in that area of Ptolemy II ;-)

If I do get stuck in there, I may implement a new Triq SequencePlotter actor directly on XYGraph.

title: NA
body:
Ptplot is a very old Java program that is based on the X11 XGraph program that was written in C.  Thus, the API and formatting is a bit baroque.

As you probably have gathered, the interface is defined in ptolemy/actor/lib/gui/PlotterBaseInterface.java, so implementing those methods would give you a good start on plotting something useful.

The harder part will be dealing with the configuration settings such as axis labels etc. and converting those from Ptplot to what ever plotter you are using.

There is a chapter in the Ptolemy book about Ptplot, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/books/Systems/chapters/SignalDisplay.pdf

title: Small improvements in editor : hide internal actor parameters + show actor icon in graphical editor figures & outline
body:
1. For the moment parameters from ptII like LimitedFiringSource.NONE are polluting the graphical actor view.
   These are more like constants, and don't seem to be relevant for an end-user configuring a workflow model.
   There are others like WindowProperties, used in Display actor etc.
2. It would be nice to reuse the actor icons from the palette, to also show them in the actor figures and in the outline tree view.

title: Small improvements in editor : differentiate multiports vs singleports
body:
1. show single-channel ports in black and multiports in white, as in ptII
2. try to prevent drawing a connection to a singleport that is already connected

title: Dual License Triquetrum under EPLv1.0 and EPL-1.0-BSD
body:
The University of California (UC) has a problem with the patent clause in EPL.  The concern is that if a UC employee (someone who has signed the UC patent agreement, which includes funded students) unknowingly contribute software that is covered by a patent held elsewhere in the UC system, then there is a conflict.  One workaround is to have UC contributors sign an individual contributor agreement.

Jay pointed out that there is the possibility of dual licensing Triquetrum as other projects have proposed doing and presumably done so.

https://projects.eclipse.org/proposals/eclipse-advanced-visualization-project  says:

> Licenses: 
> Eclipse Distribution License 1.0 (BSD)
> Eclipse Public License 1.0
> 
> Legal Issues: 
> 
> As far as the proposers know, no one owns the trademark to the project name.
> 
> Many, if not all, of the third-party dependencies in the initial contribution have already received
> preliminary approval in Contribution Questionnaires (CQs) filed by existing Eclipse projects.
> 
> We have selected both EDL and EPL for licenses because technology such this will most likely be in
> demand by many scientific institutions, some of which may not want to use it under the terms of the
> EPL. The project lead is willing to provide a justification letter for the IP-Team, Executive Director and
> the Board if required. For its part of the initial contribution, Oak Ridge National Laboratory/UT-Battelle,
> LLC approves of the dual licensing.

The EDL-1.0-BSD at https://www.eclipse.org/org/documents/edl-v10.php states:

> Eclipse Distribution License - v 1.0
> 
> Copyright (c) 2007, Eclipse Foundation, Inc. and its licensors.
> 
> All rights reserved.
> 
> Redistribution and use in source and binary forms, with or without modification, are permitted provided that the following conditions are met:
> 
> ```
> Redistributions of source code must retain the above copyright notice, this list of conditions and the following disclaimer.
> Redistributions in binary form must reproduce the above copyright notice, this list of conditions and the following disclaimer in the documentation and/or other materials provided with the distribution.
> Neither the name of the Eclipse Foundation, Inc. nor the names of its contributors may be used to endorse or promote products derived from this software without specific prior written permission. 
> ```
> 
> THIS SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED BY THE COPYRIGHT HOLDERS AND CONTRIBUTORS "AS IS" AND ANY EXPRESS OR IMPLIED WARRANTIES, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE ARE DISCLAIMED. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE COPYRIGHT OWNER OR CONTRIBUTORS BE LIABLE FOR ANY DIRECT, INDIRECT, INCIDENTAL, SPECIAL, EXEMPLARY, OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES (INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, PROCUREMENT OF SUBSTITUTE GOODS OR SERVICES; LOSS OF USE, DATA, OR PROFITS; OR BUSINESS INTERRUPTION) HOWEVER CAUSED AND ON ANY THEORY OF LIABILITY, WHETHER IN CONTRACT, STRICT LIABILITY, OR TORT (INCLUDING NEGLIGENCE OR OTHERWISE) ARISING IN ANY WAY OUT OF THE USE OF THIS SOFTWARE, EVEN IF ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGE.

To close this bug, we need to:

1) Get the OK to use both licenses
2) Define what text goes in to files
3) Update the license files.

For 1) Get the OK to use both licenses, https://eclipse.org/legal/ says:

> Eclipse Distribution License (EDL): The BSD license used by some Eclipse projects which require 
> dual-licensing along with the EPL. Other than for example code or build scipts, use of this license by
> an Eclipse project is on a case-by-case basis and requires unanimous approval of the Board of 
> Directors. 

For 2) Define what text goes in to files
Some guidance may be found at https://eclipse.org/legal/eplfaq.php#DUALLIC:

> For Eclipse projects which are dual-licensed, your file headers state that the code is being made 
> available under two licenses. For example: "This program and the accompanying materials are made 
> available under the terms of the Eclipse Public License v1.0 and Eclipse Distribution License v. 1.0 
> which accompanies this distribution." What is meant by the use of the conjunction "and"?
> The code is being made available under both of the licenses. The consumer of the code can select 
> which license terms they wish to use, modify and/or further distribute the code under. 

For 3) Update the license files, this can be done if and when 1 and 2 are done.

title: NA
body: We need to talk to @waynebeaton about this. You should email this thread to emo@eclipse.org (which just goes to Wayne).

title: NA
body:
I do not see how dual-licensing the project solves UC's concerns. Dual-licensing means that the contributions would come in under _both_ licenses, and the patent grants in the EPL would still apply.

To me the simplest solution is in your first paragraph: UC committers should sign the individual committer agreements. In fact, as far as I know UC is not a member of the Eclipse Foundation, so that is what UC committers would have to do in any event.

title: NA
body:
I think I misunderstood the issue that UC has with the EPL. At least in previous discussions with them (for ICE) they refused to allow LBNL employees to create projects and release them under the EPL, but they were free to contribute to them subject to the ICA. 

I was also thinking about this from the standpoint of other Berkeley projects using Triquetrum and refusing to do so because of the EPL and UC's complaints against it. This was the big reason we requested dual licensing for EAVP: there are significant community projects who won't use it under the EPL.

So, I may have raised the idea of dual licensing without fully understanding the problem and for that I apologize. I think Mike is right that dual licensing doesn't solve the contribution problem.

title: NA
body:
It seems that dual licensing will not solve UC's problem with the EPL.

Some projects at Berkeley were able to use the [Educational Community License, Version 2.0 (ECL-2.0)](https://opensource.org/licenses/ECL-2.0), which says:

> "The Educational Community License version 2.0 ("ECL") consists of the Apache 2.0 license, modified to change the scope of the patent grant in section 3 to be specific to the needs of the education communities using this license. The original Apache 2.0 license can be found at: http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0"

Section 3 is:

> "3. Grant of Patent License.
> "Subject to the terms and conditions of this License, each Contributor hereby grants to You a perpetual, worldwide, non-exclusive, no-charge, royalty-free, irrevocable (except as stated in this section) patent license to make, have made, use, offer to sell, sell, import, and otherwise transfer the Work, where such license applies only to those patent claims licensable by such Contributor that are necessarily infringed by their Contribution(s) alone or by combination of their Contribution(s) with the Work to which such Contribution(s) was submitted. If You institute patent litigation against any entity (including a cross-claim or counterclaim in a lawsuit) alleging that the Work or a Contribution incorporated within the Work constitutes direct or contributory patent infringement, then any patent licenses granted to You under this License for that Work shall terminate as of the date such litigation is filed. Any patent license granted hereby with respect to contributions by an individual employed by an institution or organization is limited to patent claims where the individual that is the author of the Work is also the inventor of the patent claims licensed, and where the organization or institution has the right to grant such license under applicable grant and research funding agreements. No other express or implied licenses are granted."

If the Eclipse Foundation and UC were able to agree on a similar license that was based on the EPL, then perhaps Triquetrum could have a single license, and organizations like UC Berkeley could join the Eclipse Foundation.  I realize that having Eclipse adopt a different license for some packages is not very practical and not very likely.  In addition, the patent clause in the EPL provides a modicum of protection for the users of the EPL-licensed software. Modifying the EPL to be like the ECL reduces that protection, which is also probably not palatable.

The downside is that UC won't agree to the the EPL as is, which means that UC cannot join the Eclipse Foundation.  This means that we are losing an opportunity to train students in how to directly collaborate as a part of their organization with the open source community.  Yes, UC students, staff and faculty may sign Individual Committer Agreements as a workaround, but we are missing out on an opportunity.

I don't think there is much else to be done here, so I'll close this issue in a few days if there is no further discussion.

body:

Hi Mike,

I'm not that proud of UC Berkeley, but I am (mostly) proud of what what 
Berkeley has done with open source software.  I don't like denying that 
I work at UC Berkeley.

Once it became clear that I would need to sign an ICA if I wanted to

Foundation.  I was told that it would be difficult for Berkeley to join

In a perfect world, students, staff and faculty at UC would be able to

I don't agree with the guidelines from the UC Office of the President,

_Christopher

title: Prepare an example of  a bundle that adds extra actors to the default Triquetrum actor library
body:
A subset of the std PtolemyII actors is already provided in 2 bundles in the current Triquetrum package. They are ptolemy.actor.lib and ptolemy.domains.sdf (for SDF-specific actors). This already illustrates the modular fashion in which actors can be contributed. But the editor palette is currently centrally defined in org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.editor.palette.

The goal of this issue is to deliver a small extra actor bundle and a second palette contribution that can together be uploaded as a feature in a prepackaged Triquetrum RCP. The end result should be that the default palette is extended with the new actor(s), and that the actor(s) can be used in workflow models.

Another topic in this issue is to write-up a short doc on how to do this for people knowledgeable with standard Ptolemy II actor development.

title: NA
body: Code committed in a new examples folder & doc written on  https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Extending_Triquetrum

title: Workflow Run button not visible in toolbar for a freshly created model
body:
When a new workflow model is being created, the "Run Workflow" button does not appear in the toolbar. 

You first need to add some model elements, close the model and then reopen it.

title: Implement Ptolemy II's relation Vertex
body:
ptolemy.moml.Vertex is a sub-class of ptolemy.kernel.util.Location. It is an Attribute of a ptolemy.kernel.Relation that represents a location in a model that can accept links to an unbounded number of ports. A plain Relation, without Vertex can only connect 2 ports. The moment one Relation should connect more than 2 ports, a Vertex is needed.

A Relation-with-Vertex also allows to indirectly connect multiple ports to a same single-port, via the Vertex. (1 link goes from the single-port to/from the relation's vertex, and from there multiple links can go to/from the other ports)

The way the concept is mapped to MOML and to the live in-memory representation is not 100% clear to me, but we need a similar feature in the Triquetrum editor, i.e. some way to represent it in the EMF model as well.

title: Add editor support for Ptolemy II's attributes and textual annotations on the model canvas
body:
A workflow model represents a Ptolemy II CompositeActor. The editor should also allow to drag-n-drop attributes and textual annotations from the palette, that are then stored as attributes on that CompositeActor. 

Furthermore we need to ensure that Ptolemy II's expressions and variable substitutions work as expected, so that actor parameters can refer to the values of the "model" attributes/parameters.
This should work without extra work, normally.

title: Triquetrum - ICE integration demo : create a file-based workflow model repository
body:
To be able to access available workflow models from ICE , we will provide a first implementation of org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.WorkflowRepositoryService , based on plain file-based storage.

(this is a migration of an existing similar implementation in Passerelle)

title: Implement import/export of Ptolemy II MOML files
body:
The Triquetrum editor currently stores models in EMF XMI.

It should be possible to exchange model files with Ptolemy II's tools like Vergil, so must support import/export of MOML files.

title: Implement a minimal representative workflow for demo in ICE
body:
We should start from an ICE reflectivity CSV file and run a data series from it through a moving average (a.k.a. smoothing).

The workflow could have one model parameter to identify the CSV data file.

The result could be either :
- a Plot shown by a plot actor.
- a result file that could then be handled by an ICE "resource component".

We'll go for the plot actor at first.

title: Integrate support for SVG figures and other existing Ptolemy icon definition formats
body:
Ptolemy has many existing actor figures/icons with lots of user-friendly details. It would be virtually impossible to have to reprogram those using the default Graphiti shape-programming.
Ideally we should implement a generic thing that can create shapes or figures or ... from existing SVG fragments or Ptolemy icon definition XML.

Relevant info from forum msgs at 
https://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/1075351/
https://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/m/649266/
https://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/76048/
https://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/m/650289/

So GMF SVGFigure seems a possible approach :
https://wiki.eclipse.org/Graphical_Modeling_Framework/Tutorial/Part_2#Use_SVGFigure
https://wiki.eclipse.org/Graphical_Modeling_Framework/Models/GMFGraph#SVG

Download from :
https://www.eclipse.org/gmf-tooling/download.php

Besides SVG, Ptolemy also (mainly?) has an own set of graphical attribute types that are assembled in icon definition MOMLs.
E.g. /ptII/ptolemy/actor/lib/MovingAverageIcon.xml with contents like :

``` xml
<?xml version="1.0" standalone="no"?>
<!DOCTYPE property PUBLIC "-//UC Berkeley//DTD MoML 1//EN"
    "http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/xml/dtd/MoML_1.dtd">
<property name="MovingAverageIcon" class="ptolemy.vergil.icon.EditorIcon">
    <property name="rectangle" class="ptolemy.vergil.kernel.attributes.RectangleAttribute">
        <property name="_location" class="ptolemy.kernel.util.Location" value="[-5.0, 0.0]">
        </property>
        <property name="width" class="ptolemy.data.expr.Parameter" value="60">
        </property>
        <property name="height" class="ptolemy.data.expr.Parameter" value="40">
        </property>
        <property name="centered" class="ptolemy.data.expr.Parameter" value="true">
        </property>
        <property name="fillColor" class="ptolemy.actor.gui.ColorAttribute" value="{1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 1.0}">
        </property>
        <property name="_renderFirst" class="ptolemy.kernel.util.SingletonAttribute">
        </property>
    </property>
    <property name="line" class="ptolemy.vergil.kernel.attributes.LineAttribute">
        <property name="_location" class="ptolemy.kernel.util.Location" value="[-15.0, -9.0]">
        </property>
        <property name="x" class="ptolemy.data.expr.Parameter" value="15.0">
        </property>
        <property name="y" class="ptolemy.data.expr.Parameter" value="0.0">
        </property>
    </property>
    <property name="line2" class="ptolemy.vergil.kernel.attributes.LineAttribute">
        <property name="_location" class="ptolemy.kernel.util.Location" value="[-15.0, 7.0]">
        </property>
        <property name="x" class="ptolemy.data.expr.Parameter" value="15.0">
        </property>
        <property name="y" class="ptolemy.data.expr.Parameter" value="0.0">
        </property>
    </property>
...
    <property name="Annotation8" class="ptolemy.vergil.kernel.attributes.TextAttribute">
        <property name="textSize" class="ptolemy.data.expr.Parameter" value="9">
        </property>
        <property name="textColor" class="ptolemy.actor.gui.ColorAttribute" value="{0.0,0.0,0.0,1.0}">
        </property>
        <property name="fontFamily" class="ptolemy.data.expr.StringParameter" value="Serif">
        </property>
        <property name="text" class="ptolemy.kernel.util.StringAttribute" value="1">
        </property>
        <property name="_location" class="ptolemy.kernel.util.Location" value="[-6.0, -20.0]">
        </property>
    </property>
</property>
```

title: Triquetrum First Release: 21st October 2016
body:
Our goal is to have a first release of Triquetrum on 21st October 2016 as part of a combined [Eclipse Science Workgroup](21st October 2016) release.

In the perfect world, we would have Bug #18: Create a CapeCode Triquetrum product fixed.

Also, it would be helpful, if the Bug #70: Open Ipzilla issues for Triquetrum third party code was closed.

title: NA
body:
At this point, we have one other remaining bug for the Science2016Release Milestone: Bug #113 Need a way for OSGi Bundles to add MoML filters.

Erwin and I discussed Bug #113 and he will update it.

At this point, we have a M1 release available on the [Eclipse download site](https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/technology.triquetrum/downloads)

After we get feedback about the release documents, we can create a RC1 build.

Probably the way to do this is to create a branch on this bug, update the version numbers, commit, push, pull the changes and then run the [Triquetrum Hudson Build](https://hudson.eclipse.org/triquetrum/job/triquetrum/).  Then, once we get things working and have a final production release, we need to update the Hudson Build so that we don't overwrite our 0.1.0 release and then create a new branch that has the new version numbers and commit, push and pull request that new version.  The devil is in the details of the versioning.  

See the [Tycho Versioning Plugin](https://eclipse.org/tycho/sitedocs/tycho-release/tycho-versions-plugin/plugin-info.html) for one way to do this.

To close this bug, we need to have the Triquetrum 0.1.0 downloads available and the nightly build building nightly installers.

title: NA
body: The release was done!

title: UI info in output?
body: I spoke with colleagues at SNL who have been testing Triquetrum. They said that they found UI information in the output file that stores the workflow? I haven't had a chance to look into this, but I'm thinking maybe some of that is showing up in the EMF-generated XML?

title: NA
body:
Currently we're using one XMI file to store both the Graphiti Diagram EMF model and the Triquetrum workflow model (linked to each other).
This is the simplest approach to start with, but may not be ideal in the long run.

It is possible to split both models in separate files, which is what I did at the time for Passerelle as well (and there the workflow model was straight Ptolemy II MoML alongside the Graphiti XMI).
Some are in favour of the split approach, but it also has its downside : 2 files for one workflow "ensemble" are more difficult to share/version/keep-in-synch/... than 1 file.

Personally I am in favour to split it up, as my background is more in "headless" runtimes and we could imagine running the workflows without requiring Graphiti dependencies then.
Or even linking it to other graphical representations...

Any ideas/opinions are welcome!

title: NA
body:
Another thing : for the ICE integration demo we did for EclipseCon, the demo workflow was exported from Triquetrum into straight Ptolemy MoML XML, which effectively removes the Graphiti elements.

So that's another option we could consider : the editor works in XMI (mixed or split, whatever), and outside of the editor we can still use Ptolemy MoML exports for runtime environments.
(although I don't consider this the best approach myself)

(Ptolemy MoML can also contain limited graphical info like icon types and (x,y) locations of the workflow elements, but it's much more focused on the actual workflow graph than on graphical diagram info.)

And one more thing to keep in mind : Triquetrum has a Java API org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.WorkflowRepositoryService that provides some encapsulation on the physical storage method, and returns only the "pure" workflow definition. So if we enforce the usage of that interface when integrating Triquetrum, the actual file format would be less important.

title: NA
body:
I prefer to have one file.

In Triquetrum, awhile back, I believe I noticed that strings like the 
value of a FileParameter were duplicated in the file.  This seems risky, 
so I prefer one file that has a minimal amount of duplicated information 
if possible.

FWIW, The Kepler workflow project uses .kar files which are zip files 
that contain a .moml (Ptolemy Model Markup Language) file and other 
information.  As a code maintainer, I find these files difficult to work 
with when doing operations on the files outside of the tools.  For 
example, sometimes it is necessary to update something in the files or 
clean something up.  In principle, using a  MoML filter to open the 
file, fix the problem and write the file is possible, but sometimes a 
quick and dirty script is much faster.

Another downside of a zip file is that the version control diffs are not 
that useful, though with some tooling it is possible to get meaningful 
information from diffing two .kar files

However, I think model users find the single .kar file to be helpful.  
My interactions with model files is not typical.

So, if we want to have multiple files, it might be nice to bundle them 
in one file, like what the Kepler workflow system does.  Or, I'm 
guessing Eclipse has something similar.

A non-graphical tool should be able to ignore any graphical information 
in the model description file.

For those of you unfamiliar with Ptolemy, ptolemy.moml.MoMLParser is 
used to parse the xml model description.  MoMLParser invokes filters 
that look for certain elements and perform certain operations.  For 
example, ptolemy.moml.filters.RemoveGraphicalClasses does what the name 
suggests.

In principle, using XSLT can do much of what the filters do, but with 
the filters we can inspect the model as it is being parsed.

One key thing to keep in mind is that a MoML file is not a complete 
description of the model because the model instantiates classes, which 
can include actor oriented classes, which are declarations of 
collections of actors that can be instantiated and extended.

_Christopher

> 
> Personally I am in favour to split it up, as my background is more in 
> "headless" runtimes and we could imagine running the workflows without

title: Workflow editor leaks SWT resources
body:
PtolemyModelElementShape's DrawingStrategy-is never dispose the allocated Fonts and Colors (tested with Sleak SWT tool). After a while eclipse become totally unusable. (org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: No more handles)
I'm working on a fix.

I didn't get around yet to build/use font/color registries.

I have introduced a JFace ResourceManager in the TriqDiagramBehavior. It is disposed when closing the diagram & makes sure that redrawing identical fonts/colors reuses the previously created instances. So two improvements in one shot.

The resource manage is used in the drawing strategies.

I've done some manual testing with sleak and it seems to behave correctly now.

title: Save As not selectable
body:
After the fix to bug #65, it looks like the Save As menu choice is not selectable.

When I start Triquetrum and it shows me a model, I expect to be able to Save As the model without modifying the model.

If I modify the model, then Save As remains unselectable.

This is a minor issue.

title: Support for Actor Oriented Classes
body:
Triquetrum needs to be able to support Actor-Oriented Classes, which is where a chunk of functionality is defined as a set of actors and that chunk can be extended.

Details to follow.

title: NA
body:
[From discussion with Erwin]

In Ptolemy, the Sinewave composite is an actor-oriented class, so supporting this is fairly important.  However, we could also substitute in a non-actor-oriented class.

One possibility would be to initially only support setting parameters of actor-oriented classes, which is how Passerelle works.

Another issue is where do we store classes.  In Ptolemy, the AOC files are stored on the classpath, which is tricky in a OSGi environment.  This ties in to how do we store files in Triquetrum?  One file or two files?

title: NA
body:
It could be that Xtext and multi page editors could help here. 

Multipage editors are used for the xml plugin editor.

Multipage editors were used for the Passerelle editor and to drill down.

Graphiti can be embedded anywhere.

Perhaps we should look at what ELK is doing?

title: NA
body:
I'll try to start using the WorkflowRepositoryService API to store/retrieve AOCs. It will imply providing at least a simple Preferences page (cfr #183) to be able to configure the physical location of the repository.

For the moment the repo API is still defined on Ptolemy II CompositeActor etc, which is handy for a first phase : just try to support using AOCs that have been prepared with Ptolemy/Vergil, and being able to configure AOC parameters.

In a second phase , we must be able to create/edit AOCs in Triquetrum and then the repo API must be able to handle Triquetrum models besides or i.o. Ptolemy ones.

title: NA
body: Current ideas and status have been described on the wiki : https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Actor_Oriented_Classes

- How to disable and renable formatting was documented in https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Coding_Style#Disabling_Formatting

title: Test out integrating Kepler code into Triquetrum: Use DDP/Hadoop as driver.
body:
At this time, Triquetrum does not include direct support for Hadoop.

Triquetrum uses Ptolemy II as its execution engine.  The Kepler Scientific Workflow System (https://kepler-project.org/) also uses Ptolemy II as its execution engine.  (BTW - when I refere to Kepler, I'm referring to the Kepler Scientific Workflow System which predates Kepler the Eclipse release, and probably predates the Kepler Lua package).

Kepler (Scientific Workflow System) does have support for Hadoop, see

http://users.sdsc.edu/~jianwu/JianwuWang_files/ICCS-bioKepler.pdf

https://kepler-project.org/developers/interest-groups/distributed/configuring-hadoop-for-biokepler-or-ddp-suite

My understanding of how Kepler's Distributed Data-Parallel (DDP) works is that it presents a facade for the different big data systems.   If I remember correctly, there are directors such as the Stratosphere Director that support a limited set of data types.  These directors handle the glue for the different big data systems.

Our goal with Triquetrum is to be able to support Kepler, but I have not yet tried it

Triquetrum does supporting adding actors, see https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Extending_Triquetrum

One thing that might be missing is that Kepler has a tabbed parameter editor that is not yet supported.

It would be helpful to try this before the ICCS talk on June 7, 2016.

title: NA
body:
I started https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Kepler, which documents the steps I've taken.
The biggest issue is that the ExecutionChoice actor does not properly split the action code from the UI code, so it has dependencies on classes like KeplerGraphFrame, which extends ActorGraphFrame.  ActorGraphFrame is not a part of Triquetrum.
There are about 1600 errors still.  A number of them are Access restrictions.

For example KeplerClassChanges has this warning:

```
Description Resource    Path    Location    Type
Access restriction: The constructor 'ClassChanges()' is not API (restriction on required library '/Users/cxh/src/workspaceTriq04Mar/.metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.pde.core/.bundle_pool/plugins/ptolemy.moml_11.0.0.201605041253.jar') KeplerClassChanges.java /org.kepler.triquetrum.ddpDemo/src/org/kepler/moml/filter   line 51 Java Problem
```

The code is

```
    /** Update Ptolemy's ClassChanges filter. */
    public static void initialize() {
        ptolemy.moml.filter.ClassChanges changes = new ptolemy.moml.filter.ClassChanges();
```

The problem is probably that ptolemy.moml.filter.ClassChanges is not exposed in the module.

Here is the current list of Eclipse errors:
[KeplerTriqErrors01Jun.txt](https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/files/294617/KeplerTriqErrors01Jun.txt)

title: NA
body:
From https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Kepler#Status:

As of June 7, 2016, porting the Kepler ExecutionChoice actor to Triquetrum is partially complete. The ExecutionChoice actor was chosen because it is an arbitrarily complex actor that would not be an easy port. The primary issue is that the ExecutionChoice code uses the Swing-based BasicGraphFrame code that is not present in Triquetrum. The next step would be to get the ptolemy.actor.lib.hoc.Case actor working in Triquetrum because the Case actor has internal models that need to be viewable. Right now, the UI uses ptolemy.vergil.modal.CaseGraphFrame and CaseGraphTableau, which use BasicGraphFrame, which is not present in Triquetrum because Triquetrum does not use the Swing-based viewer. After that, the next step would be to refactor ExecutionChoice to follow the Case example where the UI is in ptolemy.vergil.modal.CaseGraphFrame and CaseGraphTableau.

The current work is in checked in to a repository, see [Kepler Triquetrum Repository](https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Kepler_Triquetrum_Repository).

title: Copy and paste of actors does not work
