body: copy/paste related code was not yet migrated from Passerelle's graphiti trials

title: NA
body:
It turns out that there is quite a bit to copy and paste in Ptolemy II.

See ptolemy/vergil/basic/BasicGraphFrame.java for the CopyAction() and PasteAction()
- When we copy an actor that refers to a variable into a container that does not define that variable, then the variable should be created in the container.  See ptolemy/moml/MoMLVariableChecker.java and ptolemy/data/expr/UndefinedConstantOrIdentifierException.java
- Typically, changes are queued up as MoMLChangeRequests.  See ptolemy.kernel.undo for how to undo those changes.
- See ptolemy/vergil/OffsetMoMLChangeRequest.java for how to offset objects that are created in the toplevel.

title: Add support for Python actors
body:
Based on the code originally written by me and extended by Matt Gerring to implement Python actors this bug is to track adding the functionality to Triquetrum.

I am working on bringing the code in https://github.com/erwindl0/python-rpc up to date after Erwin extracted the code from DAWN a couple of years ago.

Some of the key things I am doing:
1- Support for Python3
2- Strip out unneeded code, especially on Python script side.
3- Prepare code for inclusion into Triq code base, e.g. code formatting, target platform, etc.

title: Use Target Platform Definition DSL and Generator to define target platform
body:
_Originally created at bugzilla before I remembered that Triq has its own tracker: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=496322_

Instead of using .target files directly, instead use tpd files (Target Platform Definition DSL and Generator files, from https://github.com/mbarbero/fr.obeo.releng.targetplatform). This allows a textual representation of the target platform that is easier to read, edit and merge than the xml one.

Pull request on the way for this, along with the Python AnalysisRPC work.

title: Can't change a port from a non-multiport to a multiport
body:
1. Start up Triquetrum
2. Search for a RecordDisassembler and drag it in to the canvas
3. Double click on the RecordDisassembler and click on Output ports
4. Click on the + button, add an output port named "output".  Do not click on multiport.
5. Click OK. The port appears as a filled in triangle
6. Double click on the RecordDisassembler and click on Output ports
7. In the "output" port line, click on Multiport
8. Click OK.  The port should appear as a hollow triangle, but it does not.

I've found a way to intercept such changes with graphiti features and will investigate more.

I would like to add the approved drmaa artifacts to orbit. Their approach (which I've used to add apache xml rpc etc for the python integration) is based on "eclipse bundle recipes". This uses bnd to transform "original" non-bundled jar artifacts from a maven repo (typically maven central) in eclipse approved bundles.

DRMAA is not available via Maven Central (and I added some tweaks in the original drmaa Java api to support usage in an OSGi runtime), so there's an issue of how to get this integrated in orbit.

Luckily it seems this kind of need is now supported since a couple of days : 
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=484631
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=484633
https://repo.eclipse.org/content/repositories/orbit-approved-artifacts/org/eclipse/orbit/

So once the CQs are approved (which depends on Board approval of the SISSL license), this will be to way forward.

Triquetrum has been updated to use Neon and the Hudson build for Mac shows Neon in the splash screen and works.

We are using the swt fragments from Gunnar's P2 repo. See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=491951#c35

For notes, see https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Target_Platform_Definition

title: Need a way for OSGi bundles to add to the MoML Filters
body:
A Java package can appear at most in one loaded OSGi bundle in an application.

We have a number of Ptolemy II OSGi bundles that have completed the Contribution Questionnaire process for third party libraries (see https://wiki.eclipse.org/Development_Resources/Contribution_Questionnaire#Third_Party_Libraries and Bug #70: Ipzilla issues for Triquetrum third party code)

If someone wants to add a Ptolemy actor that is in one of the packages in one of the bundles that have passed review, then either the bundle needs to be re-reviewed or the actor needs to be renamed.

In general, we don't want to request frequent reviews.

So, we should augment the system so that a bundle can register a MoMLFilter that will cause the MoMLParser to read in a model file that refers to the actor with the old ptII package name and instead look up the new Triquetrum package name.

See also  https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Ptolemy/Porting

title: Create a p2 site for the Ptolemy II bundles
body:
Now that the Ptolemy II bundles have completed the CQ IP process, we need to update the [https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Ptolemy/osgi-2-0 osg-2-0 build] on the [http://terra.eecs.berkeley.edu:8080/job/ptIIosgi/ Ptolemy II Jenkins osgi-2-0 build] to create the p2 site and update a website with this information.

After that is done, the .tpd files should be updated to refer to the new location.

See https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Ptolemy/osgi-2-0#Setting_up_the_p2_repository

title: NA
body:
The summary is that I have set up p2 site at https://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0/.
However, it does not quite work yet.

Details below:

I have a p2 site set up as part of the osgi-2-0 build on http://terra.eecs.berkeley.edu:8080/job/ptIIosgi.  At the end of the build, the contents of releng/org.ptolemy.tycho.update/target/*\* are copied to ~www/cvswww/chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/. A symbolic link from ~www/cvswww/chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0 to ../releng/org.ptolemy.tycho.update/target/repository was created, so the update site may be found at https://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0/

The problem is that if updating the tpd siteto use the new p2 site fails because the ptolemy classes are not found.

Details:

1) Close the org.eclipse.triquetrum.dependencies project.  Can we just delete this project?  If it is not closed, then you will get errors about ptolemy.vergil.kernel.attributes missing because that package is not present in the dependencies project.

2) Edit org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform/org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform.tpd so that the old site is not used and the new site is used:

```
// location "http://users.telenet.be/triquetrum-ptolemy-p2/" {
//      org.eclipse.triquetrum.ptolemy.feature.source.feature.group lazy
//        org.eclipse.triquetrum.ptolemy.feature.feature.group lazy
//}
location "https://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0/" {
     org.ptolemy.tycho.feature.feature.group lazy
}
```

3) Right click on the tpd file and click on Create Target Definition File

org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform/org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform.target now contains:

```

<!-- generated with https://github.com/mbarbero/fr.obeo.releng.targetplatform -->
...
    <location includeMode="slicer" includeAllPlatforms="true" includeSource="false" includeConfigurePhase="true" type="InstallableUnit">
      <unit id="org.ptolemy.tycho.feature.feature.group" version="0.0.0"/>
      <repository location="https://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0/"/>
    </location>
```

4) Open the target and click on "Set as Target Platform

5) The build will fail, there will be many problems because the ptolemy classes are not found.

However, if, in the target window (org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform/org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform.target), I press reload and then Set as Target Platform, the build works without problems!

If I save org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform/org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform.target, then it now contains:

```
<location includeAllPlatforms="true" includeConfigurePhase="true" includeMode="slicer" includeSource="false" type="InstallableUnit">
<unit id="org.slf4j.api.source" version="1.7.2.v20121108-1250"/>
<unit id="org.slf4j.impl.log4j12.source" version="1.7.2.v20131105-2200"/>

<unit id="org.hamcrest.library" version="1.3.0.v201505072020"/>
<unit id="org.junit" version="4.12.0.v201504281640"/>
<unit id="org.slf4j.api" version="1.7.2.v20121108-1250"/>
<unit id="org.slf4j.impl.log4j12" version="1.7.2.v20131105-2200"/>
<unit id="javax.xml" version="1.3.4.v201005080400"/>
<unit id="javax.xml.bind" version="2.2.0.v201105210648"/>
<unit id="javax.xml.stream" version="1.0.1.v201004272200"/>

<repository location="http://download.eclipse.org/tools/orbit/downloads/drops/R20151118145958/repository/"/>
</location>
<location includeAllPlatforms="true" includeConfigurePhase="true" includeMode="slicer" includeSource="false" type="InstallableUnit">
<unit id="org.ptolemy.tycho.feature.feature.group" version="0.0.0"/>
<repository location="https://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0/"/>
</location>
```

Note that the comment about "generated with" is missing.

So, what I think is going on is that I'm not properly creating feature.

The content.xml file in https://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0/content.jar defins the following unit for org.ptolemy.tycho.feature.featue.group:

So, the question is how to make it so that the content.xml file on the chess p2 update site does not include the duplicate requirements.

title: NA
body:
The fix was to update the osgi-2-0 repo and remove the ptolemy and diva plug-ins from the feature and category.

The p2 repo is now being updated automatically from the osgi-2-0 Jenkins job at http://terra.eecs.berkeley.edu:8080/job/ptIIosgi/

Details are at https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Ptolemy/osgi-2-0#The_Ptolemy_II_osgi-2-0_p2_repository

title: NA
body:
The dependencies project can (should) indeed be deleted, as far as I can 
tell.

Op 8/30/2016 om 8:11 PM schreef Christopher Brooks:

> The summary is that I have set up p2 site at 
> https://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0/.
> However, it does not quite work yet.
> 
> Details below:

> The problem is that if updating the tpd siteto use the new p2 site 
> fails because the ptolemy classes are not found.

> delete this project? If it is not closed, then you will get errors 
> about ptolemy.vergil.kernel.attributes missing because that package is 
> not present in the dependencies project.

> 2) Edit 
> org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform/org.eclipse.triquetrum.target.platform.tpd

title: Make the ptII source and class files that passed CQ IP review available via a p2 site
body:
Now that we have a p2 site, we need to make the ptII source and class files that passed CQ IP review available.

The jar files may be found via bug #70.

We should verify that the files that are submitted correspond with what is in the tree.

A branch or tag should be created in the osgi-2-0 repository to keep the state of what was submitted.  If we create a branch here, then we could continue to modify the osgi-2-0 branch until we are ready to submit a new set of jars.

The jar files that were submitted are what we should distribute via a p2 site.   We should create a separate static p2 site based on the previous site.  The site should contain both the source and class files.  We can create a directory in the osgi-2-0 branch that has the site and the jars.  The nightly Jenkins osgi-2-0 build can copy that directory to the Chess site.

The triquetrum tpd file should be updated to use the static p2 site that contains the approved jars.

The site build from the osgi-2-0 tree can remain in place for development.

title: NA
body:
The source jars have been checked in to the osgi-2-0/releng/cqd/plugins.  The directory name "cqd" is short for CQ'd.  These 3rd party jar files can move, but should probably not be checked in to the Eclipse Triquetrum repository because they are 3rd party jar files.

```
-rw-r--r--  1 cxh  staff   667766 Aug 30 17:05 diva.source_11.0.0.201608300001.jar
-rw-r--r--@ 1 cxh  staff     8210 Aug 30 16:08 org.ptolemy.commons.source_11.0.0.201605041253.jar
-rw-r--r--@ 1 cxh  staff    15687 Aug 30 16:08 ptolemy.actor.lib.gui.source_11.0.0.201605041253.jar
-rw-r--r--@ 1 cxh  staff   328060 Aug 30 16:08 ptolemy.actor.lib.source_11.0.0.201608160848.jar
-rw-r--r--@ 1 cxh  staff  1650011 Aug 30 16:08 ptolemy.core.source_11.0.0.201605041253.jar
-rw-r--r--@ 1 cxh  staff    71258 Aug 30 16:08 ptolemy.domains.process.source_11.0.0.201605041253.jar
-rw-r--r--@ 1 cxh  staff   145844 Aug 30 16:08 ptolemy.domains.sdf.source_11.0.0.201511291837.jar
-rw-r--r--  1 cxh  staff   469741 Aug 30 16:10 ptolemy.gui.source_11.0.0.201608231732.jar
-rw-r--r--@ 1 cxh  staff   266218 Aug 30 16:08 ptolemy.moml.source_11.0.0.201605041253.jar
```

The contents of the jar files were compared with the contents of the osgi-2-0 tree and updates made.  Note that the diva source jar file that was uploaded to IPZilla did not have the proper patch.  A new jar file was created and uploaded.  That jar file is above.

A branch of the osgi-2-0 branch was created to maintain the set of CQ'd jars.  To check out the branch of the branch, use:

```
svn co https://repo.eecs.berkeley.edu/svn/projects/eal/ptII/branches/osgi-2-0-cq-1 
```

The next step is to create a p2 site that includes the source jars and jar files containing .class files.  It is unclear to me whether the jar files containing .class files should have the same version number as the source jars, but it seems like they should.

title: NA
body:
In the osgi-2-0-cq-1 branch, pom.xml was updated so that running 

```
mvn org.eclipse.tycho:tycho-source-plugin:plugin-source
```

creates source jar files.   osgi-2-0-cq-1/releng/jar diff is a script that diffs the jar files, which are substantially the same, except for these issues:

The newly created diva source jar file, which has package.html, README.txt and makefile files, which should probably be removed from the repository.

title: NA
body:
Done!

The p2 site for the sources Ptolemy sources that were cq'd is

http://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0-cq-1

To update:

```
svn co https://repo.eecs.berkeley.edu/svn/projects/eal/ptII/branches/osgi-2-0-cq-1
cd osgi-2-0-cq-1
mvn verify
```
Then the contents of ./releng/org.ptolemy.tycho.update/target/repository were transferred to the Ptolemy web server.

See https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Ptolemy/osgi-2-0

title: Conform to Incubation Branding
body:
Triquetrum is in incubation status.  We need to conform to the branding

https://wiki.eclipse.org/Development_Resources/HOWTO/Conforming_Incubation_Branding says:
- [x] "1. Is in the Incubation phase."

The above is done.
- [x] "2. Correctly displays the incubation logo on their project home page."

The above is done, see https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/technology.triquetrum
- [x]  "3. Correctly displays the same incubation logo on their project's primary download page."

The above is done, see https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/technology.triquetrum/downloads and https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Downloads
- [x] "4. All downloadable zip files for builds and milestones must include the word "incubation" in the filename. For example, DSF-SDK-incubation-N20070413-0200.zip   The jar files in the download zip file are not required to contain the word "incubation" in the filename. (See bug 178944   for the explanation.)"

The above is not done.
- [x] "5. All "Bundle-Name"s must include the word "incubation". Note that "Bundle-SymbolicName"s should not include "incubation" because the Bundle-SymbolicName is a technical namespace, not a user namespace. For example, Bundle-Name: Foo Plug-in (Incubation)"

The above is not done
- [x] "6. Similarly, the names for update manager features must include the word "incubation". For example, Eclipse Platform (Incubation)"

The above is not done.

> Projects are listed as conforming or non-conforming on the main /projects page by the egg (conforming) and egg-with-red-slash (non-conforming) icons. If you believe your project is conforming (i.e., 1-5 above) but is listed as non-conforming, send email to emo@eclipse.org and ask us to update the database

title: NA
body:
To solve 4, that the zip files need to have incubation in their names, I edited Triquetrum.product and updated the ID to "org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.editor.rcp.incubation"

To solve 5, I used a sed script:

`
sed  -i .bak 's/\(^Bundle-Name:.*\)/\1 (Incubation)/' */META-INF/MANIFEST.MF examples/*/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF
`

To check this, I built the Target, then Eclipse->About Eclipse, Installation Details, Plug-ins, then sort by Provider.

As part of this change, I added "Eclipse Triquetrum" as the Provider to a few MANIFEST.MF files

The remaining issue is for an update manager, which I will look into.

title: NA
body:
About Eclipse -> Installation Details show that the Triquetrum features and plugins say (Incubation).

Closing this one.

title: Fix up new line problems in the repo
body:
When I clone the triquetrum git repo on a Mac, a number of files have Windows line ending characters.  This causes problems with scripts that operate on files.

To close this issue, we need to add a .gitattributes file as per https://help.github.com/articles/dealing-with-line-endings/ and then clone the repo on a non-Windows machine and not find any Windows line endings.

title: NA
body: I understand how to fix this, I'll wait for Erwin to get to a good state before I attempt to submit a pull request.  Probably what I will do is start a new branch based on the master, fix the new lines and then commit and do a pull request.

title: NA
body:
Fixed !

Running

```
rm -rf triquetrum
git clone https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum.git
cd triquetrum
find . -type f | grep -v .zip | grep -v .jar | grep -v .gif > /tmp/f
 cat /tmp/f | xargs ~/ptII/util/testsuite/controlm > /tmp/cms
```

Yields a /tmp/cms file that contains:

```
./.git/index  has controlms
./.git/objects/pack/pack-b65242fc9bc53e63c96480a9a16559339184d90d.idx  has controlms
./.git/objects/pack/pack-b65242fc9bc53e63c96480a9a16559339184d90d.pack  has controlms
./examples/org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.actor.plot.palette/icons/plot.png
Skipping ./examples/org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.actor.plot.palette/icons/plot.png, it probably is not a text file
```

title: Sign Triquetrum Bundles
body:
https://www.eclipse.org/projects/handbook/#resources-builds says:

> Where technically sensible, all downloadable artifacts should be signed by an Eclipse Foundation-provided certificate.

and has a link to https://wiki.eclipse.org/JAR_Signing

I'm putting this on the Science2016Release Milestone, but we can drop it if need be.

title: NA
body: A detailed description of how to set that up : http://www.codetrails.com/blog/sign-your-eclipse-project

title: NA
body: See also https://wiki.eclipse.org/IT_Infrastructure_Doc#Sign_my_plugins.2FZIP_files.3F

title: NA
body:
I found that it was easiest to start with https://github.com/eclipse/ice/blob/master/org.eclipse.ice.parent/pom.xml 

One possible issue is that in Triquetrum, eclipse-jarsigner-plugin is version 1.0.1.  However, in Ice, it is 1.1.3.  When I tried 1.1.3, I got 

> [ERROR] Plugin org.eclipse.cbi.maven.plugins:eclipse-jarsigner-plugin:1.1.3 or one of its dependencies could not be resolved: Failure to find org.eclipse.cbi.maven.plugins:eclipse-jarsigner-plugin:jar:1.1.3 in http://download.eclipse.org/technology/m2e/maven/ was cached in the local repository, resolution will not be reattempted until the update interval of m2e-cbi has elapsed or updates are forced 

I updated the triquetrum Hudson build so that we are using the eclipse-sign profile.

I verified that the Mac download at https://hudson.eclipse.org/triquetrum/job/triquetrum/lastSuccessfulBuild/artifact/org.eclipse.triquetrum.repository/target/products/ has signed Triquetrum plugins and features.

To close this, we need to fix Bug #148 Make releases available on the Eclipse download server and Bug #145 Create a p2 update site and verify that the jars are signed.

In addition, we should sign the osgi-2-0 jar files with the Ptolemy II code signing certificate or create a separate issue with a later milestone.

title: NA
body:
The releases are available on the the Eclipse download server and at least the Mac release contains signed plug-ins

The p2 update site contains signed plug-ins.

I created bug #178 Sign the Ptolemy Plug-ins, which has a 2017 Spring Release milestone.

Closing this one.

title: Update versions to be less than 1.0
body:
https://www.eclipse.org/projects/handbook/#release-faq says:

> 1. What restrictions are placed on version names for incubating projects?
> 
> Projects in the incubation phase generally use version numbers that are less than 1.0. This is, however, a convention not a rule. If it makes sense for you community and adopters to use higher numbers, then do so. If you’re not sure, ask your top-level project PMC for advice.

So, we should update the version numbers of our bundles and product to be less than 1.0.  I'm going to go with 0.1.0.

title: NA
body:
Updated the version number to 0.1.0.

The command that was used was:

`sed -i ''  's/\(^Bundle-Version:.*$\)/Bundle-Version: 0.1.0.qualifier/'  examples/*/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF *triq*/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF`

title: Add about.html files
body:
The checklist at https://wiki.eclipse.org/Development_Resources/HOWTO/Release_Reviews#Checklist states:

> Every bundles contains an about.html file as required by [A Guide to the Legal Documentation for Eclipse-Based Content](https://www.eclipse.org/legal/guidetolegaldoc.php).

The legal guide has a checklist for Abouts:
- [x] 'Every plug-in has an "about.html", usually the standard one.'
- [x] 'Every plug-in with a non-standard "about.html" contains the additional referenced license files.'
- [x] 'Every JAR’ed plug-in stores linked files in "about_files"'

title: NA
body: Closing this, though it will need to be checked when we are ready to submit to a release review.

title: NA
body: Check that any plug-ins that use Ptolemy jars also have the Ptolemy license.

title: NA
body:
I modified the diva and ptolemy plugins so that they have about.html files, which means that the Triquetrum plugins don't need about.html files that have the Ptolemy license.

I think this is ready to be closed.  I'm assigning this to Erwin so that he may check it against  A [Guide to the Legal Documentation for Eclipse-Based Content](https://www.eclipse.org/legal/guidetolegaldoc.php) or close it.

title: NA
body: I think this is complete indeed.

title: Complete the Software User Agreement (SUA) checklist: notice.html and epl-v10.html
body:
The checklist at https://wiki.eclipse.org/Development_Resources/HOWTO/Release_Reviews#Checklist states:

> Every bundles contains an about.html file as required by [A Guide to the Legal Documentation for Eclipse-Based Content](https://www.eclipse.org/legal/guidetolegaldoc.php).

The guide to legal documentation has a Software User Agreement (SUA) checklist
- [ ] Every build distribution has the standard SUA in the root as "notice.html"
- [ ] Every build distribution has a copy of the primary license(s) in the root, e.g., "epl-v10.html"

notice.html is at https://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl/notice.html
epl-v10.html is at https://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html

title: NA
body: How to add files to the top level with tycho is documented at https://wiki.eclipse.org/Tycho/Demo_Projects/RCP_Application and http://help.eclipse.org/neon/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.pde.doc.user/tasks/pde_rootfiles.htm

title: NA
body: Fixed!

title: Complete the guide to legal docs checklist for all Triquetrum features
body:
The checklist at https://wiki.eclipse.org/Development_Resources/HOWTO/Release_Reviews#Checklist states:

> Every bundles contains an about.html file as required by [A Guide to the Legal Documentation for Eclipse-Based Content](https://www.eclipse.org/legal/guidetolegaldoc.php).

The guide to legal documentation has a Feature Checklist
- [x] Every feature has the standard SUA in HTML in "license.html"
- [x] Every feature has the Project’s primary license(s) (e.g., typically the EPL in "epl-v10.html")
- [x] Every feature has the standard SUA in plain text in "feature.xml <license>" or "feature.properties / license"
- [x] Every feature plug-in has copyright notices, etc. in the "blurb" property of "about.properties"

title: NA
body: I believe that this work is complete, but  checking would be a good thing.

title: NA
body: Check that features that depend on ptolemy jars have the Ptolemy license.

title: Source files require license notices
body:
The checklist at https://wiki.eclipse.org/Development_Resources/HOWTO/Release_Reviews#Checklist states:

> Every bundles contains an about.html file as required by [A Guide to the Legal Documentation for Eclipse-Based Content](https://www.eclipse.org/legal/guidetolegaldoc.php).

The guide to legal docs says:

> 4.4 Notices in source code
> 
> The Basics:
> 
> Where practical, all source code (which includes Java source as well other types of files such as XML, HTML, etc.) should contain appropriate copyright and license notices as well information on each contribution.
> 
> The Details:
> 
> The standard format for these notices can be found at www.eclipse.org > Legal Stuff > [Default Copyright and License Notice](https://www.eclipse.org/legal/copyrightandlicensenotice.php).
> 
> If the source is to be licensed under a license other than or in addition to the EPL, you must ensure that the Eclipse Foundation has approved the notice.
> 
> The Location:
> 
> In the source code.

body: This looks like the right thing to use: https://wiki.eclipse.org/Development_Resources/How_to_Use_Eclipse_Copyright_Tool

title: Python connectivity fails when launching workflow editor from eclipse workspace
body:
This is on Windows 10 64 bit, with python 2.7.3 32 bit.

When exporting the Triq RCP product (for win 64 bit), running  a workflow with a python actor runs well.

When launching the product from inside my Triquetrum workspace I can try python scripts in 2 ways, in the same running equinox instance :
- using the osgi console runScript test command (from org.eclipse.triquetrum.python.service.example): then it works fine
- using the same workflow as mentioned above and launching it from the editor : the PythonService.getActiveClient(int) never obtains an active response.

In that last case, the getActiveClient() keeps getting errors in the line :  
`final Object active = client.request("isActive", new Object[] { "unused" });`

The error is :
"org.apache.xmlrpc.XmlRpcException: Failed to read servers response: Connection refused: connect". 
The retry loop keeps on trying until timeout...

The python.exe process is running, and is never terminated.

When running the script using the runScript test cmd, the same code gets executed as in the workflow actor, from inside the same running platform. And then the client.request() invocation has a success response form the 1st try. (and the python.exe is correctly terminated at the end as well)

title: NA
body:
To reproduce and/or investigate

The test model is in [testPython.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/files/465897/testPython.zip)
1. update your local triq repo to current master
2. run the /org.eclipse.triquetrum.repository/Triquetrum.product from inside your workspace
3. create a plain test project in your triq editor RCP
4. unzip and copy the attached model in your test project and run it

You should get a timeout exception after a while.

Now export the product and run it outside of your workspace and try the same. The python actor should work fine then.

Now back in your eclipse workspace, add the bundle org.eclipse.triquetrum.python.service.example to your launch configuration and run again from your workspace. The workflow should still go in timeout, but now you can try from the OSGi console something like : 

osgi> runScript helloworld input1=hi input2=ho
hello world : hi and ho
{output3={key1=hi, key2=ho}, output4=hey, output1=1, output2=[D@7c4c8b0d, output5={key1=hey there, key2=3, key3=[Ljava.lang.Object;@1e2bb6c6}, output0=1}
osgi>

i.e. the script integration works fine then, from the same running platform as the RCP editor.

title: NA
body:
Might be related to loading of system scripts by the python process somehow (although I fail to see the way the python process might be impacted by the "triq side" doing its thing from a test command or form an actor) : 
- when running from the runScript cmd (or external RPC) the python process consumes about 4.6 MB as indicated in windows task manager
- when running from a workflow, the python process sticks to 1.1 MB

title: NA
body:
Finally found some time to look at this. 

One additional setup step is to configure the Python Actor block to have the script path set to helloworld within this location in git: examples/org.eclipse.triquetrum.python.service.example/scripts/helloworld.py

title: NA
body:
When I run this workflow on Linux\* using Python2.7 it just works.
Can't test Python3 as Python3 is not supported yet.

\* I am using Xubuntu 16.04 and the system Python 2.7.12

I'll try in WIndows 10 next.

title: NA
body: Looks like it is failing as described on Windows 10 with  Python 2.7.12 (from anaconda)

title: NA
body: The problem looks like it is on the Python side. I can see the python processes running, but the process is not listening to the port.

title: NA
body:
The problem has to do with how the input on the python process is redirected. The problem is:

processBuilder.redirectInput(Redirect.INHERIT);

if it is replaced with processBuilder.redirectInput(Redirect.PIPE); or removed then everything is fine.

Now on to figure out why.

title: NA
body:
OK. I understand the problem and have a proposed fix. 

If you run in the dev environment without the -console (OSGi console) then there is no contention for stdin. But Python really shouldn't be inheriting stdin in this case and that is what the change is.

title: NA
body:
That's a great find! (if that is correct belgian english ;-) )

> 
> If you run in the dev environment without the -console (OSGi console) 
> then there is no contention for stdin. But Python really shouldn't be 
> inheriting stdin in this case and that is what the change is.

title: Create a p2 update site
body:
We need a p2 update site for Triquetrum.  We have one for osgi-2-0.

To this requires setting up the build to create the proper files.  We could start with the Jenkins installation at http://terra.eecs.berkeley.edu:8080/job/ptIIosgi/ and then try to set it up with the Eclipse Hudson installation.

body: See https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Ptolemy/osgi-2-0#The_Ptolemy_II_osgi-2-0_p2_repository for how it was done for the osgi-2-0 tree.

title: NA
body:
I think the way to do this is to
1. Figure out how to build the p2 site.  See https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Ptolemy/osgi-2-0#The_Ptolemy_II_osgi-2-0_p2_repository 
2. Possibly edit org.eclipse.triquetrum.repository/publish.xml and, if the copy and copyZips targets are not sufficient, add an ant target that copies the update site.
3. Then perhaps we should add a separate Hudson job that is a copy of the triquetrum job, but has an ant task that does the copy.

See https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Releng/Milestone_Builds for details.

title: NA
body:
I'm part way through this, I created org.eclipse.triquetrum.update.

Still to be done: fix up version numbers, test, upload.

title: NA
body:
The update site is at  http://download.eclipse.org/triquetrum/update

The triquetrum Hudson job has a second ant command that does the update by running the copy target in org.eclipse.triquetrum.update/publish.xml

Still to be done: fix up version numbers to match incubation guide.  Test by installing new software.

title: NA
body:
Woot!  This worked!  I was able to 
1. start Neon with a empty new workspace
2. Help -> Install new software
3. Add a new update site with URL: http://download.eclipse.org/triquetrum/update
4. Select Triquetrum, click through the install
5. Create a new project
6. Right click on the project, select New -> Workflows -> Triquetrum Workflow model
7. Drag in actors!

Also, About Eclipse -> Installation Details show that the Triquetrum features and plugins say (Incubation).

Closing this.

title: NA
body:
Seems we've been a bit too optimistic...

Basic things are there, but several elements don't work in the editor : director can not be added, actor cfg panels don't open etc.

This is probably related to a combination of : bundle start settings not OK, missing dependencies (EMF Forms?) in feature definitions etc.

title: NA
body: Ah well, it was a nice feeling while it lasted.

title: NA
body:
There is some overlap between the role and contents of org.eclipse.triquetrum.update and org.eclipse.triquetrum.repository

After running a local mvn build, I see there are p2 repositories generated in both of their target folders.

When installing from the p2 repo in the ...repository project, in a fresh Neon RCP edition, I get a functional Triquetrum editor.

When doing the same from the ...update project, the editor is only partially functional.

Remark that when trying the same with Neon.1 there are some warnings about mismatched feature versions during the install and the editor is also partially crippled...

The p2 repo in the ...repository project contains probably an (almost) complete RCP including all kinds of eclipse IDE bundles, as it's based on a product build. So the trick will be to find the minimal subset of all those plugins/features that is installable in a plain Neon and results in a working Triquetrum...

title: NA
body:
Ok, I've figured out what the issues are : missing dependencies  +  bundle starts. 

When running or installing from a product, the start instructions and levels are applied from the product definition. When installing from the update site though (as defined in the ...update project), not all bundles area started. And that causes all kinds of triq services to be missing, including those to obtain the ptolemy actor classes, UI module declarations, workflow execution svc etc.

To get this resolved the following things are needed : 
- add more detailed dependencies in the different feature.xmls + define the update sites where they can be found
- add p2.inf instruction files next to the MANIFESTs of the bundles that must be started (to run their activator, get DS components activated etc)

The p2.inf task has impact both on the ptolemy bundles and in Triquetrum.

title: NA
body:
Woot - bis! It works now!

Take a standard Neon RCP eclipse for instance (not a Neon.1!)

And then install Triq from the update site http://download.eclipse.org/triquetrum/update/ and you're all set to investigate simple Ptolemy workflows!

body:

files, that did not solve it.

Thanks for handling this.

_Christopher

title: Review the UI Guidelines and Checklist
body:
The [Triquetrum 0.1.0 release plan](https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/technology.triquetrum/releases/0.1.0/edit) includes a section about Release Documentation:

> Usability
> Summarize the usability of the software. Usability in this sense is about using the software from the end-user's point-of-view, not the more academic sense of UI evaluation/testing. Summarize the user interface usability and the conformance to the [User Interface Guidelines](http://wiki.eclipse.org/User_Interface_Guidelines). If appropriate, include discussion of section 508 compliance (you can discuss multiple language support in the Internationalization section, below). Explain any deviations from the user interface guidelines and standards.

To close this, we need to:
1. Review the [User Interface Guidelines](http://wiki.eclipse.org/User_Interface_Guidelines)
2. Complete the [UI Checklist](https://wiki.eclipse.org/UI_Checklist)
3. Update the Usability section of the [Triquetrum 0.1.0 release plan](https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/technology.triquetrum/releases/0.1.0/edit)

There is a problem with the javadoc Tycho module, so I've commented it out.

Christopher wrote:

> ...Our code freeze is on Tuesday 9/13 in part because I'm traveling the remaining part of the week and Erwin is busy the following week. If we submit a release questionnaire on 9/13 or 9/14, is that sufficient time for the October 21 release date?  It seems like two weeks is sufficient, but I just wanted to double check.  I'm aware of https://www.eclipse.org/projects/handbook/#release-review, which says that the release review process takes a week and that the release reviews take place on the first and third Wednesdays.  My intention was to create a release on Tuesday 9/13 via the "Create a Release" under the committer tools.

title: It is not possible to change a port between and input and an output
body:
From Bug #95:

It is not yet possible to change a port between input&output, and the current cfg dialog has some unergonomic duplicate concepts. I.e. an actor has an input port list and an output port list but still the user must check the port types as well.

I would leave that until after the release, as the solution for this involves a non-trivial change in the underlying EMF model.

title: NA
body:
Basic behavior is in place. The EMF model has been adapted to have one list of all ports, combined with getters for input ports and output ports. The actor config dialog now has a single table for all ports, with the checkboxes to mark them as input/output/multiport. When changing from input to output and vice-versa, the actor shape is updated after Ok-ing.

Two open issues remain : 
- how to block the properties of the ports defined in the actor code (similarly to Ptolemy vergil's approach, while allowing them to be editable for dynamically added ports. This seems to be difficult/impossible with EMF forms viewmodels. Maybe need to check out EMF Parsley that uses DSLs i.o. declarative models.
- define the port layout for ports that are both input&output (and what about ports that are marked as neither?

(The code is on the branch erwin/bg/158/change-port-type, not yet merged in master)

title: NA
body:
Christopher,

I've merged work that should fix most of the port type-changing issues:
- The actor configuration panel has been simplified to just show one port table.
- Ports can be changed between input&output (or both)
- Added a "direction" concept (similar to Ptolemy) to place ports on one of the 4 actor sides

There is an annoying issue in the port table in the actor config dialog : enums don't get rendered yet as comboboxes, but as plain text. When opening the port cfg dialog from that table, it gets rendered as combo though. I've reported this to EMF forms and it should be resolved soon : 
- forum : https://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/1084921/
- bugzilla : https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=513592

Still to do : rotate the port shape to always point inwards for an input & outwards for an output.
For the moment it still always points from left-to-right.

Can you try this out already and let me know what you think about it?

thanks
erwin

title: NA
body:
PR #207 contributes what I would propose as currently sufficient fix for this issue. Review/feedback is very welcome!

Not sure what's the right way to comment on remaining issues : in the PR and/or this issue, so I copy some info here from the PR  #207 : 

Known remaining issues depend on EMF Forms limitations. I would prefer to handle them in separate future issues :
- how to make some settings in a an actor's port table read-only for predefined ports (i.e. defined in the actor code) while allowing them to be edited for ports added via configuration? And similar how to prevent deletion of the predefined ports.
- using a combo box in the port table, for the Direction property

title: NA
body:
This looks pretty good.  The enum problem is a bit annoying, I agree that handling it in a separate issue is fine, please go ahead and create them and then close this one.

On other minor issue is that if a port is both an input and an output, the icon should reflect that.  This is a minor issue, should I open a separate issue for it?

title: NA
body: I'll use a shape similar to the one used in Ptolemy II for input/output.

title: NA
body: Ports that are both input and output are confusing and not often used in Ptolemy II, but now the Triquetrum editor supports them.

title: Resolve the gaps with eclipse UI guidelines
body:
Triquetrum 0.1.0 is already compliant with most of the UI guidelines, but there are still some gaps.
The goal is to prioritize them and resolve most of them by the 2017 Spring release.
- [ ]  1.7 : no localized resources yet for our own labels and content
- [ ]  1.9 : error handling is not yet complete. Most errors get logged via plain logging, but no user notification dialogs yet nor integration with Eclipse logging view.
- [ ]  2.8 : icon types follow what is supported in Graphiti. No strict rules yet about SVG icons in Graphiti context bar and other diagram icons can be of different types (i.e. are mostly gifs or SVG, not always png)
- [ ]  2.17 : folder/subfolder structure not followed. The very limited nr of icons/images is maintained in one simple folder
- [x]  6.21 : editor & outline are not yet linked, but via the graphical outline one can already quickly jump to a selected position in the diagram
- [ ]  6.22 : error/status info not yet shown in the outline
- [x]  7.21 : link between editor tab and package/project explorer selection not yet implemented
- [ ]  8 : there is no custom perspective yet

title: NA
body:
1.9 : started using StatusManager etc for error handling, to define UI dialog and/or logging to std Eclipse error log
will now figure out 7.21 first : that was easy, it just works ;-)
next is 6.21

title: NA
body: 6.21 done

Hi Hugo,

The errors are coming from the Equinox Declarative Services startup, as 
we've still got detailed logging activated.
But the DS service retries a couple of times and then finds the 
components. So this should not impact the workbench state after the full 
startup is finished.

For the moment we don't have a custom perspective yet. To get started, 
you just need to create a plain eclipse project in your workspace and 
then do a File > New > Other and select the Triquetrum entry in the 
Workflows section.

This is documented on https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Getting_Started

Can you try if that works for you? Let me know if there would still be 
an issue.

Remark that the actual actors available in the editor are still limited.
I have attached 2 sample workflows that you could copy in your project 
to play with (hope this gets attached correctly to the github issue, 
from a simple email reply)

regards
erwin

title: NA
body:
I just commited a branch in my fork. It has a basic perspective with just the Project Explorer and the Editor Area. It is meant to work with the Eclipse IDE and not with with standalone RCP.

I had to do the following to add the plugin and be able to run it:
- Added org.eclipse.triquetrum.ui.e4 to org.eclipse.triquetrum.core.feature
- Updated the depencies of org.eclipse.triquetrum.core.feature by selecting Compute in the Dependencies tab.
- Added required features in the content page fof the Triquetrum.product by selecting Add Required.
- Deleted the current run configuration and created a new one from the product defintion.
- Added -clearPersistedState to the Arguments tab of the run configuration.

The reference for adding the perspective to the Eclipse IDE is:

https://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/1079673/

title: Allow extra actor bundles to contribute to existing palette groups
body:
When adding extra actors with their own palette contributions via the corresponding extension points, it is not yet possible to add new actors in an existing palette group. I.e. referring to an existing group name just creates a new group with that duplicate name.

The behaviour should be to add the new actors in the single existing group.

title: Create Preferences page(s) for Triquetrum and its services
body:
Several parts of Triquetrum could use an approach to make them configurable. 
E.g. the number of threads reserved for the WorkflowExecutionServiceImpl, maybe the actor library/palette contents for the workflow editor etc.

In Eclipse RCP the standard approach is to provide Preference pages.

title: NA
body:
This is indeed the standard approach for **global** settings which are common for all application such as the file-system location of a specific library. There is an option for changing preferences on a per project basis but doing so should be an exception rather than the norm. Global default values should be common for all projects created and should be set to reasonable defaults **once** by the user and or a priori. Using the preference store is very useful for presenting and setting values when artifacts are created by the IDE such as when a project creation wizard is run or some configuration file is generated.

Given the above. Which are the global preferences neeeded? Can those global preference be categorized into groups of different functionality?

title: NA
body:
This is for global settings for a Triquetrum RCP instance, i.e. indeed 
not related to a specific project in one's workspace.

Cfr the 2 examples mentioned in the original issue description :

The workflow execution service now assigns by default a nr of execution 
threads corresponding to the available CPU cores.
This is a valid default choice, but an (advanced) user may want to tune 
that.

The actor library/palette is currently defined through plugin extension 
points.
Users may want to hide/add actors to personalize their palette via 
preferences.

Etc. we can think about more use cases.

title: NA
body: To support #78, I'll start with providing a Preferences page to configure the root location of a file-based WorkflowRepositoryService implementation.

title: NA
body: Closing this because we have some preferences available now.  A new bug may be opened in the future with specific needs for preferences.

title: Use OSGi ConfigAdmin to configure Triquetrum services
body:
Equinox also implements the ConfigAdmin and MetaType services (since Neon I think). It would be good to support configuration of Triquetrum Declarative Services via these OSGi standards i.o. being dependent on custom methods.

This is related to #183 and would imply building and integration between Eclipse Preferences (and pages) and ConfigAdmin/MetaType.

title: NA
body:
A msg on osgi-dev mentioned that currently OSGi DS doesn't play well with ConfigAdmin.
(https://mail.osgi.org/pipermail/osgi-dev/2017-September/006575.html)

As this is more a technical issue than functional, we'll postpone this until this becomes supported in a standard way.

body: I'm using CM + OSGi for years without a problem the mentioned issue on the mailinglist adresses a different issue.

title: RC1 Mac Installer is from an unknown developer
body:
Under Mac OS, when I download http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php?file=/triquetrum/RC1/org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.editor.rcp.incubation-0.1.0RC1-macosx.cocoa.x86_64.zip&mirror_id=272

and then unzip it and then click on Eclipse.app, I get a dialog about the app being from an unknown developer.

The workaround is to right click on Eclipse.app and select Open.

The fix to this is to make sure that we are signing Eclipse.app

The Windows version probably has a similar issue.

We could ship 0.0.1 without this being fixed.

title: NA
body:
(possibly also related to #188 ?)

There is some info and examples on signing applications during the build being discussed on cbi-dev : http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/cbi-dev/msg01776.html

There are win and mac signer plugins that can be configured in the pom.
It would seem this is something different from signing individual jars.

Info on those executables signing plugins : 
https://www.eclipse.org/cbi/sitedocs/eclipse-winsigner-plugin/plugin-info.html
https://www.eclipse.org/cbi/sitedocs/eclipse-macsigner-plugin/plugin-info.html

And on CBI in general : 
http://www.eclipse.org/community/eclipse_newsletter/2013/august/article3.php

title: NA
body:
I've fixed this.  The key thing was to in org.eclipse.terraswarm.triquetrum.repository/pom.xml to move the archive-product goal into the pre-integration-phase so that the signing can occur before zipping.

```
                        <plugin>
                                <groupId>org.eclipse.tycho</groupId>
                                <artifactId>tycho-p2-director-plugin</artifactId>
                                <version>${tycho-version}</version>
                                <executions>
                                        <execution>
                                                <!-- (optional) install the product for all configured os/ws/arch environments                                             
                                                        using p2 director -->
                                                <id>materialize-products</id>
                                                <goals>
                                                        <goal>materialize-products</goal>
                                                </goals>
                                        </execution>
                                        <execution>
                                                <!-- (optional) create product zips (one per os/ws/arch) -->
                                                <id>archive-products</id>
                                                <goals>
                                                        <goal>archive-products</goal>
                                                </goals>
                                                <!-- We want to get the signing done before we archive, so we assign                                                       
                                                     the archive-products goal to the pre-integration-test.                                                                
                                                     See http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/cbi-dev/msg01777.html                                                        
                                                     -->                                                                                                                   
                                                <phase>pre-integration-test</phase>
                                        </execution>
                                </executions>
                        </plugin>
```

title: The update site has unsigned content
body:
Under 64-bit Linux, I used http://download.eclipse.org/triquetrum/update as an update location and during the install was prompted with a Security Warning window that says:

> Warning: you are installing software that contains unsigned content.  The authenticity or validity of this software cannot be established.  Do you want to continue with the installation?

Under Details, many files are listed:

```
/home/cxh/.p2/pool/plugins/diva_11.0.0.201610051338.jar
/home/cxh/.p2/pool/plugins/org.eclipse.triquetrum.common_0.1.020160111927.jar
...
```

etc.

I'm not sure if this is the update site for 0.1.0RC1 or if it is from the nightly build.  We should probably have both.

I'm not sure if this should block the release, but I think we could ship 0.1.0 with this issue not fixed.

title: Define and implement a system for dynamic editor palette construction
body:
To support #18 we need to be able to build the editor's actor palette dynamically, based on external resources, i.o. the current approach that uses Eclipse extensions defined in plugin.xml files.

So we will provide a mechanism & API to define alternative palette content providers.
The idea would be to define this on the level of palette groups and to provide a first implementation that adapts to Ptolemy II's EntityLibrary concept, the org.terraswarm.accessor.AccessorLibrary in particular.

title: NA
body:
I've started a trial implementation of an adapter between AccessorLibrary loading and the Triquetrum palette.

It's at https://github.com/erwindl0/triquetrum-capecode

I've added all required deps in my workspace (by hand), i.e. vert.x core + netty + jackson and am able to start-up this extended Triquetrum. But when the AccessorLibrary tries to load the test accessor from the locally contained index.json and BaseA.js, I get an error related to required js files : 

Loading accessor failed: BaseA.js
com.microstar.xml.XmlException: XML element "entity" triggers exception:
  ptolemy.kernel.util.IllegalActionException: Failed to load basicFunctions.js
  in .CapeCode configuration.Accessors.BaseA
Because:
Cannot find file 'ptolemy/actor/lib/jjs/basicFunctions.js' in classpath in platform:/plugin/org.eclipse.triquetrum.ptolemy.capecode.palette/src/main/resources/BaseA.js at line 2 and column 54
Caused by:
 ptolemy.kernel.util.IllegalActionException: Failed to load basicFunctions.js
  in .CapeCode configuration.Accessors.BaseA
Because:
Cannot find file 'ptolemy/actor/lib/jjs/basicFunctions.js' in classpath

So now the problem becomes : being able to load all kinds of js files (and other resources?) from inside a ptolemy bundle?

title: NA
body:
Cool! Thanks for taking a look at this.

Yes, Ptolemy II looks in the classpath to find resources like basicFunctions.js.  I'm not sure how this will work with OSGi.  It is not just the JavaScript actor that looks in the classpath for resources, models can look for resources if the resource starts with $CLASSPATH.  

We had to solve a number of issues surrounding resource loading for WebStart.   See ptolemy/actor/gui/JNLPUtilities.java and nameToFile() and nameToURL() in ptolemy/util/FileUtilities.java

title: NA
body:
I've debugged into ptolemy.util.FileUtilities and there's a lot in there that is incompatible with basic OSGi approaches to find resources. 

I need to investigate this in more detail, but a first quick thought is that we may need to change the code in JavaScript and/or FileUtilities to try to be compatible with both standard Ptolemy II/Vergil and with Triquetrum/OSGi. Or in the worst case fork the code in the osgi-2.0 branch from ptII trunk...

title: NA
body:
Right, we will need to figure out how to get resources.  It would probably be best if methods in FileUtilities were modified so that they work with OSGi bundles.   For example ptolemy.actor.lib.jjs.JavaScript has a getResource() method that invokes FileUtilities.nameToURL().  So, if we fix up nameToURL(), we fix this in many places.  The main thing about FileUtilities.java is that it should not depend on OSGi classes at compile or run time.  Thus, any changes to FileUtilities.java that use OSGi classes should use reflection to invoke OSGi-specific methods.

I ran in to similar issues with WebStart, where a .jnlp file lists a series of jar files that can contain resources.  With WebStart, a class could look in the classpath for any resource and the classpath included all the jar files.  This is an old school POJO way of resource lookup, but is probably not compatible with OSGi, where jar files are supposed to be more opaque.   

The reality is that models expect to be able to use $CLASSPATH to get any resource that is in the ptII repo.

title: Triquetrum Command Language
body:
A command language to create model as described in the following document could be useful for making faster writing  big models

[TriquetrumCommandlanguage.docx](https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/files/652824/TriquetrumCommandlanguage.docx)

title: NA
body:
Great suggestion. 

Going for a command language i.o. a plain representation of a model hierarchy is an interesting approach that could map nicely to Ptolemy II's ChangeRequests and undo stacks etc.

title: NA
body:
I put some notes at https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Xtext and a link to this issue.   Below are the notes:

[Hallvard Traetteberg](https://www.ntnu.edu/employees/hal) visited the Ptolemy group in 2012-2013 and did a first cut of creating Ptolemy II OSGi bundles. Hallvard also developed some Xtext work, see https://github.com/hallvard/ptolemy. Hallvard has not been using Ptolemy much recently, but his work is there.

Ptcl was a TCL-based language for Ptolemy Classic. The [ptcl manual](http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/ptolemyclassic/almagest/docs/user/pdf/ptcl.pdf) might be of use to help define some of the Xtext commands. For example, both will need to connect ports from an outer composite to an inner composite.

title: NA
body:
The status of this issue is that Rodolfo forked the triquetrum repo to 
https://github.com/rtotaro/triquetrum.git and added a branch with his work.

Rodolfo, Erwin and I had a teleconference where Rodolfo demonstrated being able to create and connect actors and to modify an existing model.

A proposed name is Tqcl for TriQuetrum Command Language.

During the call, we agreed that the Ptcl syntax is very Ptolemy Classic-specific and should be used only as a rough guide.

The next steps are:
1) Erwin will work with Rodolfo on getting his code into the the master.  
2) Erwin will work with Rodofo on getting Rodolfo committer status on the Triquetrum project
3) Rodolfo will work on extending the language to support a flat model such as what is in http://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Opening_A_Model.  
4) A future task would be for Christopher to create a Ptolemy II code generator that would read MoML files and generate Tqcl output.  We could eventually use this for round trip testing, where we read in MoML files, generate Tqcl output, then read the Tqcl and run the model.
5) Future work would include supporting hierarchy
6) Future work would include support actor oriented classes, see Bug #78 
7) Future work could include recording the steps a user makes while using a GUI for later playback.

title: NA
body:
After our call today, we decided that Rodolfo will create a pull request and Erwin will merge it in.
Other possible action items before closing this issue:

- [ ] Update https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Xtext with how to use the work
- [ ] Add documentation to https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Tqcl
- [ ] Be sure the [Triquetrum CI Build](https://hudson.eclipse.org/triquetrum/) is working.

body:
I'll need to check about Graphiti change impact for Oxygen.

The thing about adding all those extra ptolemy imports in the ...workflow.model's MANIFEST is a bad surprise. I don't see any reason why the model bundle would need those. I'll check this out later today or tomorrow.

title: NA
body:
I'll also update the p2 refs for Orbit and ECP/EMF Forms.

With issue #203 the class loading issues will be resolved, and the ...workflow.model MANIFEST can be rolled back again then.

title: NA
body:
Remark that when using Neon as Triquetrem development IDE, you get product launch validation warnings with the latest Triquetrum target updates. 

You can just ignore it, i.e. you can still launch Triquetrum and it works fine.

It seems that a Jetty upgrade was done (which is a dependency of the Eclipse Help system), which introduced new optional "capability requirements". While the Neon PDE Product editor/launch does not handle the "optional" nature correctly.

![neonjettyreqswarning](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461921/26783342/f2d9fb58-49f7-11e7-8549-1f2dff7f3eb1.JPG)

Is resolved in Oxygen PDE.

See :   
* https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=512807
* https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=515878

title: NA
body:
Target platforms updated to the final Oxygen release (and accompanying Orbit build for Oxygen).

When review is ok, this would be the right time to close this issue...

title: NA
body: We are on the release version of Oxygen, so this can be closed.

title: Ensure correct DS bind/unbind method signatures
body:
Related to #198 : the DS/SCR implementation has been updated (based on Felix SCR now) and seems to be more strict on service reference bind/unbind method signatures.

For multiplicity-many references we currently have typical add/remove method signatures that return boolean to indicate if the method effectively updated the reference collection (loosely similar to many collection-like apis). This worked until Neon, but on Oxygen the SCR does not accept such method signatures.

Indeed in OSGi R6 compendium, void return type seems to required (cfr 112.3.2 Event Methods).

This needs fixing both in Triquetrum and in Ptolemy's OSGi-related extensions.

title: Provide an Oomph setup for a Triquetrum developer
body:
Eclipse Oomph allows to define a setup for an Eclipse IDE + a predefined workspace materialization.

The approach is to download the generic Eclipse Installer and then point to our setup file to obtain a ready-for-use Triquetrum development setup.
It would be handy for new Triquetrum developers/contributors to have such a "Triquetrum development" Oomph setup available.

For the moment, this would be about using an Eclipse Neon RCP/RAP IDE + a Triquetrum workspace configured on our current target platform (Oxygen).
Once Oxygen is released incl Oomph, we could switch the Eclipse IDE to Oxygen as well.

title: NA
body: Added description on how to use the Oomph setup in our CONTRIBUTING.md and on the [Triquetrum wiki](https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Building_From_Sources#Using_the_Triquetrum_development_Oomph_setup).

title: NA
body: The Oomph setup is pretty slick! I updated the wiki. One issue is that if for Product Version, I select Latest (Oxygen), then a dialog appears that states: The URI ' https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eclipse/triquetrum/master/setups/org.eclipse.triquetrum.developer.setup/TriquetrumDevelopment.setup' does not contain a valid product. See the screenshot below: One slightly confusing thing is that if I keep the initial default Product Version of Latest Release (Neon), then when I start up Triquetrum, the Oxygen splash screen is displayed. I feel this is correct, but what is possibly slightly confusing to a new user is that they are using Neon to build an Oxygen Triquetrum. This is not a problem, just possibly confusing.

title: NA
body:
Erwin wrote:

> https://waynebeaton.wordpress.com/2017/04/03/service-releases-of-third-party-content-in-the-eclipse-ip-due-diligence-process/
> 
> This could simplify the process to get Ptolemy updates in our Triquetrum build.
> 
> Of course it remains to be seen what we consider as service releases…
> 
> When we add extra Ptolemy classes in the bundle projects, I guess we would need a rapid CQ anyway.

See Bug #116: Make the ptII source and class files that passed CQ IP review available via a p2 site.

To see what changed:

```
svn co https://repo.eecs.berkeley.edu/svn/projects/eal/ptII/branches/osgi-2-0-cq-1 
svn co https://repo.eecs.berkeley.edu/svn/projects/eal/ptII/branches/osgi-2-0
diff -rwb -x .svn osgi-2-0-cq-1 osgi-2-0 >& ~/tmp/osgi-2-0-cq-1-diff.txt
```
See [osgi-2-0-cq-1-diff.txt](https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/files/950303/osgi-2-0-cq-1-diff.txt)

Summary of the diffs:
* org.terraswarm.accessor is a new directory, see Bug #18 (Create a CapeCode Triquetrum product)
  * osgi-2-0/org.terraswarm.accessor/original-src/ptolemy/actor/lib/conversions/json/{JSONToToken.java,TokenToJSON.java} are new files
  * osgi-2-0/org.terraswarm.accessor/original-src/ptolemy/actor/lib/jjs has lots of code that is from external sources and might be difficult to get through CQ because the licenses are not compatible.
* There are various changes to pom.xml and MANIFEST.MF files that don't need to be CQ'd.
*  ptolemy.actor.lib2 is new and would need to be CQ'd.  We might want to add more classes here, or update ptolemy.actor.lib
  * osgi-2-0/ptolemy.actor.lib2/original-src/ptolemy/actor/lib2/{Bernoulli.java,      BooleanMultiplexor.java,BooleanSelect.java,BooleanSwitch.java}
  * osgi-2-0/ptolemy.actor.lib2/src/main/java/ptolemy/actor/lib2/activator{Activator.java,                        AliasModelElementClassProvider.java}
* ptolemy.core has some changes:
  * osgi-2-0/ptolemy.core/original-src/ptolemy/data/{AWTImageToken.java,ImageToken.java} are new and would need to be CQ'd.
  * osgi-2-0/ptolemy.core/original-src/ptolemy/data/expr/Constants.java has a new method: nameToType() and some other minor changes.  This would need to be CQ'd.
  * osgi-2-0/ptolemy.core/original-src/ptolemy/util/{ExecuteCommands.java,                     StreamExec.java,StringBufferExec.java} are new and would need to be CQ'd.
  * osgi-2-0/ptolemy.core/src/org/ptolemy/classloading/osgi/OSGiClassLoadingStrategy.java  has some minor changes that would need to be CQ'd.
* osgi-2-0/ptolemy.gui/original-src/ptolemy/actor/gui/JNLPUtilities.java has a new method: getResourceSaveJarURLAsTempFile() that would need to be CQ'd.

title: NA
body:
To determine what files needed to be added to ptolemy.actor.lib:
1. export JAVAFLAGS=-verbose
2. $PTII/bin/capecode >& /tmp/c.out
3. In CapeCode, click on the copyright and the click through the bottom of the pages until the "Expand configuration" link is at the top.  Click on "Expand configuration".  This will expand the actors listed in the left hand palette and the class names will appear in /tmp/c.out
4. Generate a list of java files with: `egrep 'ptolemy\.actor\.lib' /tmp/c.out | grep -v jjs | awk '{print $2}' | sort | sed 's/\$.*$//' | sort | uniq | sed 's@\.@/@g' | awk '{print $1 ".java"}'`

Below is the diff between osgi-2-0/ptolemy.actor.lib/pt-jar.files and the proposed changes:

[pt-jar.files.diff.txt](https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/files/1253870/pt-jar.files.diff.txt)

title: NA
body: Probably the thing to do is to look at the source jars in https://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0-2/plugins/ and compare them with the submitted jars for the science triqiuetrum cq in https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/

title: NA
body:
I've compared the source jars in https://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0-2/plugins/ and  the submitted jars for the science triquetrum cq in https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/

It looks like the bundles that need to be cq'd are 

- [x] ptolemy.actor.lib
- [x] ptolemy.core
- [x] ptolemy.gui
- [x] ptolemy.moml

A few comments:
* diva: From the osgi-2-0 repo, I've removed README.txt, package.html and makefile along with some other files that are not in the diva bundle that were not cq'd.  The next build will not have these files
* The modules in https://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0-2/plugins/ are signed, the modules that we submitted in the cq last year are not.
* There are some trivial, non-functional changes in some of the modules such as comments that can be ignored
* It seems that the versions that were cq'd have plugins.properties files, yet the versions I've created at https://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0-2/plugins/ do not.  For example, the version of ptolemy.diva from https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/attachment.cgi?id=14738 has a plugins.properties file that contains:

```
##Source Bundle Localization                                                                                   
#Wed Feb 10 15:51:53 CET 2016                                                                                  
pluginName=diva.source
```
Is it a problem that the new bundles do not?

* Here are the diffs before I removed the files from diva and updated the version numbers:
[ptcqdiffs.tar.gz](https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/files/1260745/ptcqdiffs.tar.gz)

* I've updated the p2 repo at https://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/triq/p2/osgi-2-0-2/with updated version numbers in MANIFEST.MF and with the files remove from diva. (The diff above predates this update).

* Also updated Triquetrum to use the latest files in the p2 repo.

title: NA
body:
- [x] I'd be grateful if Erwin could review the ptcqdiffs.tar.gz file.
- [x] We need to figure out the plugins.properties.
- [x] Need to update the version number of the feature from 1.0.

title: NA
body:
I checked the changes, and they seem to be all fine (did it in the PtII SVN repo directly).
The detailed version updates for changed packages/bundles are a nice detail! (cfr semantic versioning)

The properties files for internationalization are not an issue. My impression is that they are a result of the build, and the difference between the CQ-ed and new source jars is related to a change in Tycho's approach I think : http://git.eclipse.org/c/tycho/org.eclipse.tycho.git/commit/?id=f290bd4e4ed15a23d231a04a402faf94b99d3213

For the feature version : wouldn't you use the highest Ptolemy bundle version nr, i.e. 11.1.0 in this case?

Thanks for catching this.

title: Model with RecordDissassembler results in unreachable actors
body:
If a Triquetrum model has an RecordDissassembler in it, then the downstream actors are unreachable.

This model has a Const with a value {RData=42} connected to a RecordDisassembler connected to a Display:

[ConstRecordDisassemblerDisplay.tdml.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/files/947681/ConstRecordDisassemblerDisplay.tdml.zip)

When I run it, the following output appears in the console:

> 2017-04-21 09:26:04,814 WARN [pool-1-thread-3]  executor.WorkflowExecutionTask (executionError:226) - Context 187aa650-363a-45f9-893f-d8a12df54635 - Execution error of model newDiagram
> ptolemy.actor.sched.NotSchedulableException: SDF scheduler found disconnected actors! Usually, disconnected actors in an SDF model indicates an error.  If this is not an error, try setting the SDFDirector parameter allowDisconnectedGraphs to true.
> Unreached Actors:
> .newDiagram.Display 
> Reached Actors:
> .newDiagram.Constant .newDiagram.RecordDisassembler 
>   in .newDiagram.SDF director.Scheduler
> 	at ptolemy.domains.sdf.kernel.SDFScheduler._solveBalanceEquations(SDFScheduler.java:856)
> 	at ptolemy.domains.sdf.kernel.SDFScheduler._getSchedule(SDFScheduler.java:564)
> 	at ptolemy.actor.sched.Scheduler.getSchedule(Scheduler.java:189)
> 	at ptolemy.domains.sdf.kernel.SDFDirector.createSchedule(SDFDirector.java:408)
> 	at ptolemy.domains.sdf.kernel.SDFDirector.preinitialize(SDFDirector.java:765)
> 	at ptolemy.actor.CompositeActor.preinitialize(CompositeActor.java:1820)
> 	at ptolemy.actor.Manager.preinitializeAndResolveTypes(Manager.java:1030)
> 	at ptolemy.actor.Manager.initialize(Manager.java:702)
> 	at ptolemy.actor.Manager.execute(Manager.java:354)
> 	at org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.execution.impl.executor.WorkflowExecutionTask.call(WorkflowExecutionTask.java:121)
> 	at org.eclipse.triquetrum.workflow.execution.impl.executor.WorkflowExecutionTask.call(WorkflowExecutionTask.java:1)
> 	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266)
> 	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142)
> 	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)
> 	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)

For reference, here is the corresponding Ptolemy model:

[ConstRecordDisassemblerDisplay.xml.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/files/947689/ConstRecordDisassemblerDisplay.xml.zip)

Needs more testing&debugging to figure out under which exact conditions this occurs.

title: NA
body:
Since the original ICE Triquetrum integration demo, the EMF model has changed in an incompatible way, a.o. while implementing #158 <https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/issues/158> . I didn’t bother yet to look for (automated) model migration tools (which EMF and its related frameworks probably do allow to build).

 

From: Christopher Brooks [mailto:notifications@github.com]

To: eclipse/triquetrum <triquetrum@noreply.github.com>
Cc: Subscribed <subscribed@noreply.github.com>

http://wiki.eclipse.org/File:ICEdemo1.zip contains ICEDemo1.tdml.

I tried to recreate the model but bug #219 <https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/issues/219>  Model with RecordDissassembler results in unreachable actors prevented me from doing so.

title: NA
body: Right, I was not necessarily expecting it to open, but when I went to recreate it, there was the Bug #219 about RecordDisassembler.  Mainly, I want to remind myself to recreate the file.

title: NA
body:
I've updated the ICEdemo1.zip file, but now the problem is:

Bug  #238 File -> Open File... does not add a file to a project

To close this issue, we need to update https://wiki.eclipse.org/File:TriquetrumModelOpened.png so that it shows ICEDemo1.tdml under the project like https://wiki.eclipse.org/images/archive/9/93/20170606230148%21TriquetrumModelOpened.png

title: NA
body: Closing this one.  I updated  https://wiki.eclipse.org/File:TriquetrumModelOpened.png so that ICEDemo1.tdml appears in the Package Explorer.

title: Parameter names are not updated in the model
body: If I drag in a Parameter, click on configure and change the name to "myParameter", then the parameter name on the canvas is not updated, even after reloading the file. Note that the tool tip has the correct parameter name: I would expect the canvas to say "myParameter:" where it says "Parameter:" However, the tdml file [ParameterNotUpdated.tdml.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/files/948041/ParameterNotUpdated.tdml.zip) has the correct parameter name: ``` ``` Although earlier in the tdml file we have: ``` ```

title: NA
body:
Christopher, can you retest before our call tomorrow?

thanks!

title: NA
body: Fixed!

title: The delete actor dialog should be optional
body: When I delete an actor, I'm prompted with a window that asks me if I want to delete that actor. Ideally, that window would have a "Please don't show me this type of window again." check box. Or, there would be a way to disable it. This is very low priority.

title: NA
body:
This is coming from Graphiti's DeleteAction implementation. 
I'll check if it can be adapted.

title: NA
body: Done. The "remember my choice" choice is linked to an editor preference that can also be (un)set in a Triquetrum preference page now.

title: NA
body: Thanks!  I've confirmed that this works.

title: It should be possible to draw relations from input to output
body:
It seems that it is not possible to draw a connection from the input of an actor to the output of an actor.

For example, if a model has two actors, a Ramp and a Display, it is not possible to mouse on the input of the Display and drag the connection to the output of the Ramp.

This is a low priority task.

title: NA
body: Indeed. I thought this would be good to start a connection in the right "direction", i.e. from output to input. If that's not desirable, I can look at changing that.

title: NA
body: Should be resolved now, can you test it out?

title: NA
body: Thanks, this is fixed, I can draw relations from the input to the output.

title: Mac OS X: The folder "/private/var/folders/.../AppTranslocation/.../workspace/.metadata" is read-only
body: After downloading the Mac zip file from https://hudson.eclipse.org/triquetrum/job/triquetrum/lastSuccessfulBuild/artifact/ and unzipping it, I get a dialog that states `Mac OS X: The folder "/private/var/folders/.../AppTranslocation/.../workspace/.metadata" is read-only.` https://github.com/scouter-project/scouter/issues/231 suggests adding -data /tmp https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/tlaplus/bL04c6BiYxo suggests moving the app to the Applications folder

title: NA
body: Fixed

title: NA
body:
I think this is due to the fact that you launch your RCP on a JDK 7 (cfr the 3rd line in the startup log).

Since Neon, Eclipse requires a JDK 8 to run on itself (although you can develop in it for Java 7 applications or older).

 

 

From: Christopher Brooks [mailto:notifications@github.com] 
Sent: Monday, April 24, 2017 5:56 AM
To: eclipse/triquetrum <triquetrum@noreply.github.com>
Cc: Subscribed <subscribed@noreply.github.com>

title: NA
body: Fixed! I updated Triquetrum.product: -Dosgi.requiredJavaVersion=1.8 I verified that under Java 1.7, we get an error dialog: The above dialog says: ``` Version 1.7.0_55 of the JVM is not suitable for this product. Version: 1.8 or greater is required ``` Closing.

title: Update Triquetrum Eclipse Oomph setup for Oxygen
body:
Eclipse Oxygen is getting close, we should get the installer updated.

I downloaded the Oxygen RC2 installer from https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/index-developer.php and followed the instructions in http://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Building_From_Sources which clearly state to select Neon.

See also Bug #211: Provide an Oomph setup for a Triquetrum developer

However, as a test, I selected Oxygen and the following error occurred:

> Fetching p2.index from http://download.eclipse.org/releases/oxygen/201706021000/
> Fetching content.xml.xz from http://download.eclipse.org/releases/oxygen/201706021000/ (850.62kB)
> Calculating requirements and dependencies.

title: File -> Open File... does not add a file to a project
body:
If I do File -> Open File... and open a .tdml file, then the file opens, but is not added under the project.

To replicate:
1. Download the ICEdemo1.zip file from https://wiki.eclipse.org/File:ICEdemo1.zip
2. In Triquetrum, in the Project Explorer, right click, select New Project -> General -> Project, click on Next, enter a project name click on Finish
3. With the newly created project highlighted, select File -> Open File ... and browse to the ICEDemo1.tdml file.  Click Open
4. The .tdml file will open, but is not added under the project.

See https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Opening_A_Model for screenshots

See also bug #65 File->Open should be able to open a .tdml file

title: NA
body:
This is expected behavior for the File -> Open File… menu item in Eclipse.

Its purpose is to be able to open/edit files that are not in your workspace.

 

The behavior you would like is in the File -> Import menu item.

 

So I would prefer to stick to the general behavior/expectations of those 2 actions.

 

From: Christopher Brooks [mailto:notifications@github.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, June 7, 2017 1:13 AM
To: eclipse/triquetrum <triquetrum@noreply.github.com>
Cc: Subscribed <subscribed@noreply.github.com>
Subject: [eclipse/triquetrum] File -> Open File... does not add a file to a project (#238)

 

If I do File -> Open File... and open a .tdml file, then the file opens, but is not added under the project.

To replicate:

1.	Download the ICEdemo1.zip file from https://wiki.eclipse.org/File:ICEdemo1.zip
2.	In Triquetrum, in the Project Explorer, right click, select New Project -> General -> Project, click on Next, enter a project name click on Finish
3.	With the newly created project highlighted, select File -> Open File ... and browse to the ICEDemo1.tdml file. Click Open
4.	The .tdml file will open, but is not added under the project.

See https://wiki.eclipse.org/Triquetrum/Opening_A_Model for screenshots

See also bug #65 <https://github.com/eclipse/triquetrum/issues/65>  File->Open should be able to open a .tdml file

—
